div.p: A true, and exact RELATION OF THE Difference between Mr. Christopher Cisner, one of the Pastors of the French Church in London, and others of the Consistory thereof, and John Jurin senior, Merchant, a Member of the same Church.

Wherein the treacherous dealings towards the French Churches in England, and erroneous Doctrine asserted by Mr. Cisner, and his obstinacie, either to maintein, or retract it, are discovered: As also, the unjust defending him therein by that Consistory, and their irregular proceedings against Mr. Jurin, are palpably objected to publique Consideration.
For the vindication of the said Mr. Jurin.
By publique Licence.
LONDON, Printed by William Bentley. 1657.

div.head: TO THE Reverend, and Worthy the Pastors, Elders, and Deacons of the French Churches in England, who are Members of our Colloquie, Grace, and peace to them be multiplied through our Lord Jesus Christ.
div.p: WHereas you are the onely Representative of our severall Churches, sitting in each particular Consistory; Out of whom, according to the good, ancient, and laudable Custome of our Church-government, fitting Members are to be chosen and deputed by Letters of Deputation to assemble together, whereby to compose, and form a Colloquie, which is the super-intendent power of our Churches, and hath been honoured, and acknowledged to be so, and is our onely naturall, and proper judicatory, and Judges within our selves for the ordering and regulating of all our Church affairs, for and during a very long succession of years; I have therefore to you, (As my dutie requires me,) made this present Dedication of the following Remonstrance: Wherein I do not doubt, but upon your serious perusall and Consideration, my impulsive necessity to publish the same to your View, will be most evidently manifest. To the end I might justly vindicate my self from the false, and scandalous Aspersions of Mr. Christopher Cisner & Mr. John Baptista Stouppe, and some of their Adherents, Members of the Consistory of London. And therefore give me leave, I beseech you with as much brevity as I can, to declare unto you the motives, and grounds that induce me hereunto.

Some few Members of the Consistory of London taking part
with Mr. Cisner, whereby to cover, and conceal his manifest Errors, and injuries, committed by him against the Doctrine and Discipline of our Churches, and to scandalize and abuse me together with Mr. Elias Delmey (our pious and faithfull Pastor,) and Mr. Daniel Fervacques (amongst many other Fathers of Families) in particular, did the last year, (as if it were the Act of the whole Church, when in truth it was but some part of the Consistory) print and publish a Book both in French and English: Wherein (among 〈◊〉 many other Calumnies, and reproachfull Termes.) they unworthily charged Mr. Delmey to have raised an unhappy Quarrell between Mr. Cisner, and my self and Mr. Fervacques And instead of labouring to appease it, he had kindled, and venomed it; joyning with us two in a foul Accusation which 〈◊〉 set forth against Mr. Cisner, and upholding the Quarrell with us to the very last. Although the Consistory had declared it to be false, and ill grounde • ; Hereby designing to justifie themselves, in outward, and common Appearance; by casting a Blemish, and disgrace upon us as of we should be offenders and enormous persons For clearing whereof and that our selves are innocent, and their Book false, and slanderous I commend the ensuing, Relation to your Censure Whither Mr. Cisner dealing treacherously with our Colloquie in the year 1646 by falsifying, and betraying his Deputation from them in the Case of Doct •• De Laune, and Mr. D'asigny at Norwich, as is so palpably discovered in this Book be not worthy of due Reproof, And when as also he delivered false and erroneous Doctrine in the Pulpit, and also maintained it to me and Mr. Fervacques upon the Exchange, for which I desired him to give me Christian satisfaction, by proving or denying his position he instead thereof returning ill words to me at that place by traducing Mr. Delmey and others with my self without cause, Calling us that party that troubled the Church and declining to give me any satisfaction at all. And I thereupon replying that the troubles of the Church, proceeded from one of that party, that was sent to Norwich for the peace of that Church but betrayed it, he then gave me the Lie, & accused me to the Consistory of London
that I had called him Traitor on the Exchanger And thereupon being summoned to attend them, produced my Author Mr. Fervacques who confirmed his Report made to me of Mr. Cisner's treachery, and owned the business, offering to prove it, and accordingly hath fully done it by valid and sufficient Testimony, and indeed from Mr. Cisner's, own hand writing. Yet nevertheless some Members of the Consisto • y would still unjustly hold me on with Mr. Fervacques to maintain my words: Notwithstanding since that he owned and maintained them, I ought then by all Laws and reason to be discharged from further Attendance or prosecution thereupon. And that they might the more injurio • sly deport themselves they wickedly acquitted Mr. Cisner notwithstanding the proof and evidence of 〈◊〉 offence and suspended me from the Sacrament of the Lords Supper Refusing all offers propositions and terms of putting the difference to a Methodicall Enquiry and judgement, severall times made and proposed by me to them, according to our Discipline, and government that your selves in Colloquie as my proper judges, might determine the same. And for that Cause I made my protest against them and appealed to all our Churches in Colloquie: Which by their indirect means was prevented from forming at London in January 1655 and also from assembling at Centerbury, As of common right they should have done the 12th of May 1656. And instead thereof they laboured to introduce and bring in a Coetus of the strangers Churches in London onely conjoyned with themselves, and dissolving all brotherly Communion with some of our Churches, most unnaturally would have set the Coe • us up to be the naturall judges of all our differences in our Church in London: Being directlie opposite to the verie nature and constitution of a Coetus; which is an assemblie, merelie, and onelie for consulting and ordering of Civill affairs, and hath no power or influence at all upon matters of Church government, since the establishing of our Colloquies for almost eighty years together: And by this Device would destroy and overthrow the use of our Colloquies, and in the end, and bent of their intentions, quite root up our government and banish it totallie out of our Churches. But at length, by his Highness
gracious favour we obtained the libertie of a Colloquie, which was vigoroustie opposed even before his Highness person, by Mr. Stouppe and others of Mr. C • sner's Abetters Before whom I did expect that my greivance should have received a due h • aring and full Relief. But as you will herein fully discover (besides many of your own personall knowledges thereof,) that by the irregular Actions of onelie five persons deputed to sit in Colloquie in August and September 1656. (who, being the less number of the Deputes of all our Churches concerned to sit, and refusing to receive two of our Churches, could not regularlie act as a Colloquie rightlie constituted according to our government,) all my hopes became frustrate and all our Differences left without redress; Whereby such a grand and notorious division hath happened amongst us as renders us Contemptible to the nation, wherein we live; for that being brethren of one common profession, and so ought to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace, we by our own unhappy dissention are accounted, even as common enemies one against the other. Which in truth I must confess had been (by Gods blessing) prevented, and happilie pacified, if those persons in the Consistory, who have been so active with Mr. Cisner had inclined to the Advice of Mr. Florantine • ainturier, (a godlie ancient and well experienced Elder,) and not have abused their brethren that dissented from them, as did Mr. Vancourt, and four Deacous with them in Consistory. And indeed I cannot complain against the whole Consistory in generall, but the Major part, who are lead away by Mr. Cisner and Mr. Stouppe, and three or four leading men more onely.

But for as much (Reverend and worthie Sirs,) as that the Condition of all the Churches in generall, as well as my own Case in particular, is so sad and lamentable, and that our government hath been at tempted to be pull'd down, and a new form introduced, to our verie great scandall & prejudice, and dishonour of our Predecessors, and that also contrived onelie by some few disorderlie, passionate, and unexperienced persons, and merelie out of wilfulness,
and obstinacie to countenance, and abett, and protect from justice a notorious Delinquent, (as Mr. Cisner is,) to the great dishonour of God, and trouble of our Churches, I humblie therefore beseech you to quit your selves like good Christians, by interposing your Aid, Councell, and advice, whereby to preserve, the honour and Authoritie of our Colloquies from ruine, and destruction, and also to put your judgements into action, that a Colloquie may be speedilie called, and regularlie formed, or some other means foundout; Whereby justice and right may be done to everie one grieved, and oppressed, and such Censures be imposed on persons offending as the merit of their fact shall justlie deserve: Which for my own part I am verie readie and willing to submit unto, if I shall be judged an offender. That thereby the Churches may be re established in peace, and tranquillitie and the Discipline, and government thereof defended, and protected against all opposition, and from confusion amongst our selves. And these things I humblie intreat you to lay to your hearts, and activelie prosecute, and pursue, that, what by the Religious care of our reverend, and worthie Predecessors was in the worst of times asserted and maintained, may not by our negligence, disrespect, indifference, or carelesness be deserted, and forsaken in the times of greater light, and manifestation of truth.

I should not upon any termes have made my self (being a private person, though verie much injured,) so publick as to be visible in Print, were it not, that my sincere and heartie love and affection to the order, good government, and reunion of our now sadlie distracted Churches do move me thereunto; Albeit that the scandals and hard Censures past upon me, vented even by one, that I hold to be a godly man, but partiall in his judgement, had been sufficient cause to move and stir up anie man that desires to hold faith and a good conscience, and to walk as becomes the Gospell of Christ, to vindicate himself by all due waies and means. And more especiallie when as the parties, that appose and gainsaie him, upon all Accompts where by to prevent and obstruct the verie ordinarie and direct Rule and
means of Redress, shall be so wilfull and obstinate as to refuse and reject all Propositions and offers of peace and settlement whatsoever. And that this is my case, you will manifestlie discover in reading this Book: Which for your better Information I present unto you.

And with all desire you to be pleased to consider one verie materiall Circumstance in the Case of Mr. Delmey, which is this: That at the verie time, when Mr. Delmey was suspended from his office of Presidentship, there were (as I am informed), but seven Elders of thirteen in the Consistory of London, whereof three Elders opposed, and voted against his suspension, whereby it was carried but by one vote of the Elders. This I offer, that the Churches may be advertised, how few persons in number have begun and carried on the ungodlie procedings against Mr. Delmey; who never (as I have heard) had anie Complaint made against him, by anie of the Congregation either for Doctrine, or manners: For which there have been divers Complaints made against Mr. Cisner, as being erroneous in Doctrine & scandalous in his Conversation; Nor have anie opposed Mr. Delmey, but the pluralitie of the Consistory. Which Theseech you well to consider in reference to your Observation upon the Book latelie printed, concerning Mr. Delmey and themselves, published by the Fathers of Families; that when it shall please God to instruct your hearts for the assembling of a Colloquie, or finding out some other means of deliverance of our poor Churches from distress, and violation, you may be the better prepared to act, and determine concerning our present differences. And that Almightie God will be mercifullie pleased to direct your Counsells, and Engagements for the welfare of our Churches, whereby Religion may flourish in its puritie and the power of Godliness be continued therein against all Error and Corruption, to the glorie of God, and honour of our Christian profession, is, and shall be the praiers of him, who is.

closer.signed:
Your servant in all brotherly
duty, and Communion. John Jurin Senior.

div.head: A true, and exact Relation of the Difference between Mr. Christopher Cisner, one of the Pastors of the French-Church in London, and others of the Consistory thereof, and John Jurin the elder, Merchant, a Member of the same Church.
For the Vindication of the said Mr. Jurin.
div.p:
THe Churches of the French Tongue, inhabiting in England, being assembled by their Deputies, and Proxies at London, in the year, 1644. in a Colloquie, (the Capitall, and supreme Convention for the Rule, and Government of those Churches, according to the ancient, and laudable Usage, and Custome of the Discipline thereof,) did by their Act fully, and unanimously agree to suppresse the Observation of all such daies, as were heretofore commonly called, Holy-daies; Which before that time were commemorated by those Churches; But afterwards they did decline to solemnize them; Nor have they been observed by any of them, till within a twelvemonth last past; excepting onely, that the French Church in London, (contrary to the said Act, and merely out of a perverse, and precipitate Rebellion against Ecclesiasticall Orders, designing to be distinct by themselves from all our Sister-Churches,) have lately introduced and required the Observation of such Dayes: Albeit that the said Act was confirmed, and established in another Colloquie at London, of the said Churches, in the year, 1654. At which time, some of the Consistory of the Church in London,
did, in Order to the making a Proposition by their Deputies to that Colloquie, propose in their Consistory, That Holy-daies might be again set up. Which motion was opposed by Mr. Elias Delmey, (one of the Pastors of that Church,) and some others in the Consistory; But by the Majority of voices, that Proposition was ordered to be made to the Colloquie; Whereby to have their explanation.

Upon occasion whereof, Mr. Delmey took an opportunitie to treat of that subject; Demonstrating the unlawfullnesse of observing such daies: At the hearing whereof, it was observed by some, that Mr. Cisner was very impatient; who assoone as Mr. Delmey had given the blessing, did openly before the Congregation averre, That Mr. Delmey had preached a seditious Sermon. Which was such a pertinacie, and insolent affront from a Minister to a Minister, that it is without example in all the Churches of the French tongue in England, that ever can be memorized. But at the time of the meeting of the Colloquie in September 1654. all differences were accorded in the Church; yet at that Convention the Deputies of London desired, that the Colloquie would explain the Act, made in 1644. concerning the putting down of holy daies; alledging that they had no intent to keep them. Whereupon the Colloquie declared, That that Act did prohibite unto the Churches of our tongue in England, the publique exercises on holy daies; But did not condemne, as superstitious, or Idolatrous those Churches, that practised the contrary.

Not long after the dissolution of that Colloquie, Mr. John Doneau junior of Norwich (being in London, in company with Mr. Daniel Fervacques, and others,) And discoursing about that Injury offered to Mr. Delmey by Mr. Cisner, was verie much discontented, saying, It is no marvell; for hee that will betray a Church, will make no conscience to trouble a godly Minister of the Church: And so related the particulars of what Mr.
Cisner had done, to Mr. Fervacques; who communicated the same to my selfe; Not-withstanding which, (the said difference being so newly reconciled,) Although Mr. Cisner's offence was, (as hereafter shall be described,) a most egregious Act of treachery, Mr. Fervacques, and my selfe resolved to conceale, and entombe it in oblivion, for the peace of the Church.

But the implacable spirit of Mr. Cisner, (who will not live quietly with Mr. Delmey, his religious, and faithfull Brother,) could not long confine it self in the limits of Moderation: and therefore Mr. Delmey some time afterwards preaching on a Lord's day, upon the 21th Section of the French Catechisme, touching Repentance, was controverted, and opposed by Mr. Cisner, in an other irregular manner; for that on the Wednesday following Mr. Cisner complained to the Consistory against that sermon; suggesting, that Mr. Delmey had preached against his Colleague Mr. John Baptista Stouppe (another Pastor of that Church;) whereunto Mr. Delmey replied, that he intended no such matter; for that hee had studied his sermon, before he had heard Mr. Stouppe preach the Lord's day in the morning: But this answer would not pacifie the Consistory; who being instigated by those other Pastors, proceded to make an Act of Consistory forthwith against Mr. Delmey, to oblige him against his conscience; unto which hee could not in duty, and good conscience acquiesce. But the irregularity of that complaint will be clearly manifested, if the custome and practice of the French Churches be duly considered, which is; That as soone as a Sermon is ended, the Ministers and Elders repair to the Vestry, or Consistory-house; and if a Minister hath delivered any thing not well understood, or wherewith any person is dissatisfied, it is presently proposed to him, while it is fresh in memory, to explain and distinguish. Which was not required of Mr. Delmey and therefore it may be more then conjectured, that Mr. Cisner, and
his party in the Consistory complotted, not to impeach him for his sermon presently after its delivery; supposing he could not afterwards make so positive a defence, as he might have done immediately, when the matter was obvious to the Congregation.

Hereupon the differences recovered new strength, and vivacitie; which being perceived by my selfe, and meeting Mr. Cisner, and Mr. La Roche (one of the Elders) at the Royall Exchange in London, I, (together with Mr. Fervacques) resolved to conferre with them; But by no means to cast oyle on the fire incensed, but extinguish it rather with the water of longanimity, and discretion, and in truth, to say not so much as a word, which should administer a just offence. And thus resolved, wee there accosted them; My selfe affirming, that I was verie much greived, there should bee new divisions touching Mr. Delmey's Sermon, upon repentance; but Mr. La Roche alledged, that his affaires would not permit him to stay, and so departed. Wherefore I did tell Mr. Cisner, That I heard Mr. Delmey, and in my judgement his doctrin was sound and good; whereto he replyed, It was sound: upon which I demanded, Wherefore then they made such a severe Act against him; to which Mr. Cisner retorted, Because that he preached against Mr. Stouppe, whose doctrine was also good and sound: upon which I did desire Mr. Cisner to declare, why such a severe Act should be made, since both the Pastors had preached the truth; and how, and wherein Mr. Delmey had failed: Who said, in the manner of his Sermon; and instantly fell out into a passion of anger, saying, that Mr. Delmey, and his partie troubled the Church: Whereupon I intreated him to forbear such expressions of parties, which ought not to be in the Church of God; And as they were all one Body, so they ought to be all of one minde: But Mr. Cisner seemed to defend it, alledging, that in the Church of Corinth, there was a party for Paul, another for Apollo, and another for Christ: Who
being questioned, Whither they were commended, or reproved for it, answered, that they were reproved; Wherefore with much fervency I besought him, that thenceforth he would desist to use such Terms of Division; for thereby the Church would never be in quiet.

Furthermore at the same time, and place, I had conference with Mr. Cisner about a sermon, which he had preached; wherein hee had asserted, that there was hypocrisie in the Law; telling him, that I beleived there was a Mistake in the Auditors, and that he was not well understood by them. To which Mr. Cisner replied, that he did utter somwhat to that purpose: And then said, That the law was an hypocrite, and promised that which it could not perform; & moreover, If one was born in the state of innocency (as Adam was,) and had kept the Law from point to point, yet he should not be saved by it. Unto which I returned, That it was verie strange doctrine, and I was much unsatisfied therewith. Wherefore Mr. Cisner said, That perhaps I was ignorant and knew not what hypocrisie was. Which (truely) I profest, I did not: upon which Mr. Cisner began to inform mee, that there were two sorts of Hypocrises, But abruptly declined; Passionately alledging, That I, and my partie were the troublers of the Church: which I had good cause to disclaime; and to affirm, That the troubles of the Church were from that partie, that was sent down to Norwich to settle the peace of that Church, and betrayed it. Upon which Mr. Cisner gave Mee the Lie, and said they were all liars, that affirmed it. But I saying, What if it be proved? who then shall be the Liar? Wee departed one from the other without further discourse.

Whereupon Mr. Cisner complained to the Consistory. That I, and Mr. Fervacques had called him traytor on the Exchange: To which they gave credit, and ordered Us to appear before the Consistory; And upon summons
Wee attended; The Consistory chargeing Ʋs with the premisses; And saying, That the Papists made Song's of it, and what a great Scandall, that was to Religion. Whereupon I desired to be informed, (before I answered that false Accusation,) Whither the Discipline was changed within two years past: Whereto Mr. Stouppe (then President) replyed, It was not to the matter. But at the length I saying, It should be no hindrance to my answer, and pressing as before; Mr. Stouppe said, He thought the discipline was not altered. Then I made reply, That if it was so, they had broken the Discipline; for that they, ought not to have called Mee, and Mr. Fervacques before the Consistory, till they had used the common and accustomed Practice of the Governement; which is according to the Doctrine and advice of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ in Mathew, 8: Chap. 15.16, 17. verses: Desiring them earnestly to peruse the 5th Article of the 3d Chap. of the booke of the Discipline concerning Elders; which they refused: Wherefore insisting to declare the Passages of the discourse between Mr. Cisner and my selfe at the Exchange; Mr. Stouppe required mee to come to the Fact; Iterateing those expressions severall times. Whereupon I being interrupted, said to the Consistory, that if I was not suffered to speake, I had nothing to doe there. And then they gave mee leave to proceed: which I againe assaying to doe, was still neverthelesse obstructed by Mr, Stouppe. Wherefore perceiving Mr. Stouppe's unjust designe to suffocate, and stifle the truth, I applied to the Consistory, And said.
SIRS!

BEING that you will not suffer Mee to relate what passed, I say, that the accusation of Mr. Cisner is false: For he said unto mee, That I and my partie were the troublers of the Church: I said to Mr. Cisner, Noe: it was not I, nor they that he called my Party, that troubled the Church; But it was from that party, that were sent to Norwich for the peace of the Church, and betrayed it: Mr. Cisner said, That I lyed, and all those that said it. I told him, if it be proved, who then will be the Liar, and so we parted. SIRS! His conscience reproved him so strongly, that he tooke it to himself; when as it was said of the Company. For there were five persons besides himself; And why should he take it to himselfe, but that he knew himself to bee guilty. And further I said to the Consistory: If Mr. Cisner had had the Patience to have demanded of mee, whom I meant, No doubt, but that I should have told him. Whereupon the Company in Consistory desired to know my meaning; And thereunto I answered, that I meant Mr. Cisner, and him only; for that I was fully perswaded, that the rest of the Gentlemen had done their duties according to their Commissions. Wherefore the Company required mee to tell them, From whence I had received that Information; I answered, that I had it from Mr. Fervacques (then and there present.) And Mr. Fervacques being demanded, If he had made such a Relation to mee, affirmed positively, that he had so done, and all the matters were true; And that he did speake it only of Mr. Cisner.; justifying himself in telling mee the Particularities.

Mr. Cisner hereupon called God, and the Holy Ghost to be his witnesses, that the said accusation was false; and that wee had forged it, and were inventors of Lies, and tellers of Lies. Of which Invocation, and his scandalous Expressions, Wee desired
the Company to take notice, and observe. Who said to mee, that I must yet prove my accusation; Albeit that Mr. Fervacques had owned, and asserted it before them; And thereby by the Law of God, and the Lawes of this Land, I ought not to have been further enjoyned to make any other proof; for that when I had produced my Author, there nothing more remained, but that the Author himself should proceed to mainteine, and averre his Information, and not my selfe. Upon this Mr. La-Roche, (one of the Company,) said: that I ought to be discharged by the Lawes of this Land: But Mr. Stouppe, (then President,) affirmed, that by the Lawes of France I ought not: Which being so opposite to common equity and natural reason, cannot be solidly conceived to be the usage, or practice of any Civil, or well constituted Governement: But if it be the custome of France, (not being approved, or admitted in England, where our Laws are just and right,) it is however no waies obligatory, or astrictive to any persons of the French Churches in England: For that they are not bound to any Method of procedings by their Ecclesiastical Discipline, other then according to the word of God, and the Lawes of reason, founded thereupon: Which to all Societies, and Assemblies, (professing Christianity,) ought to be their absolute Rule, and prescription, without variation, or declension.

After all this the Company demanded of Mr. Fervacques, Of whom he had received his said Information, Alledging that it must be proved; and required of him to tell them, in what time it might be done; who answered, that his evidence was farr distant from London, and it could not be produced sodainly. Wherefore they passed an Act of Consistory, and allotted him a month's time: Upon the Reading of which Act (at Mr. Fervacques request,) It appeared to mee,
that although I had produced my Author, and pressed in Justice to be disobliged from further attendance; The Company had neverthelesse engaged me equally with Mr. Fervacques, to make good that information contrary to all right reason, and good Conscience.
I shall here insent the following Article of our Discipline before-mentioned.

div.head: The 3. Chapter, (of the Discipline,)
Concerning the Duty of the Elders; (And the Ministers, and Elders are the Body of the Consistory.)
The 5th Article.
div.p: None amongst them shall bring his neighbour before the Church, (that is to say, the Consistory) for to accuse him of secret or particular faults, unlesse he hath first advertised him according to the Order, prescribed by our Saviour in the 18th Chapter of Saint Mathew. Which they shall endeavour may be observed, as well for themselves, as also for the particular Members of the Church.

By this the Reader may plainly discern, how wrongfully the Consistory behaved themselves towards me, in admitting an Information against me by Mr. Cisner, contrary to the word of God, and the constant and uninterrupted Custome and practice of all our Churches; For they ought not to have called me before them, (according to the tenor of the said Article) untill that the Elder of Mr. Cisner, and mine Elder had used their joynt endeavour to have pacified and reconciled the difference between us; And then, (having first tried those means, and no Reconciliation procured,) those two Elders ought to make their Report to the Consistory, who (if they saw it good,) might thereupon have sent for me, and not before. And thus their irregular procedings in breaking the Discipline of our Churches, have been the cause of all the difference herein related) between them and my self.

Being prohibited to make a full Declaration of the truth of the Discourse at the Exchange, between Mr. Cisner and my self before the Consistory, I therefore sent the Original in French of the ensuing translated Copy of a Letter by Mr. Peter Bar, (one of the Elders,) to Mr. Cisner, which was delivered unto him, viz.

body.p: I Am very much unsatisfied, and cannot begin quiet, till you explain, and prove your saying to me touching the Law: you, told me, It was an Hypocrite; For it promised that which it could not perform: And that under the Law, if one was born in the Estate of innocencie, as Adam was, and had kept the Law exactly from point to point, and fulfilled it; Neverthelesse he could not be saved by it. Sir, I had come to you to have received satisfaction; But I feare, that we might fall again into new disputes. Therefore to prevent it, I desire that you would bee pleased to send it mee in writing: And that will be the meanes, that I shall not misunderstand you: having not else: onely waiting your Answer. I rest.

closer.signed:
Yours, who desires to be enlightened in all truths.
John Jurin Senior.

div.p:
To which Mr. Cisner declined to return any Answer: The cause whereof is palpable to the Reader, That if he could have defended his Position or Assertion by the principles of true Christian Religion, he would not have been so averse to refuse an answer to his Christian brother. But to leave the cause (whither
presumption or ignorance,) to Mr. Cisner's own breast, wherefore he with-drew himself from giving due satisfaction unto mee; The Reader shall, (if he please,) further observe the deportment of the said Consistory toward me. For they unjustly summoned mee with Mr. Fervacques before them, (the moneths time being near expired, by them limited for proving the Accusation against Mr. Cisner, as aforesaid.) Who attended them; And Mr. Fervacques, (having received an Answer of his Letter, by way of Justification of the Accusation against Mr. Cisner from Mr Doneau, whom he had sent for according to the Consistorie's Order,) did extract so much thereof, as related to Mr. Cisner, and reading it to the Consistory, left it with them, and with-drew. Whereupon after some Consideration by them had thereupon, they called both my self and Mr. Fervacques in again; Telling us, that Mr. Cisner was not nominated, but onely a Gentleman indefinitely: By which they would not understand Mr. Cisner to be meant; But required further Testimony: Which was offered, so soon as Mr. Doneau conveniently came to London, which he promised he would do with all expedition; Supposing with all that which was in his Letter might have sufficed; Albeit he had not particularly named Mr. Cisner, to avoid (if possible,) his publick disgrace: When as the matter it self, (of which he was accused,) was to himself most evident, and notorious.

But Mr. Cisner, and his Company, (labouring to make all the Covers, and shrouds they could, whereby to cover his unfaithfull practice, in falsifying his deputation; And taking advantage of the absence of Mr. Doneau,) did again summon me, and Mr. Fervacques before them in Consistory; Who appearing, were required to make good our further evidence; The Consistory seeming very much displeased, that Mr. Cisner should lie so long under an Accusation, without any proof thereof; Threatning us to proceed against us according to the Discipline. Wherefore Mr. Fervacques assured them, that Mr. Doneau's
occasions had obstructed his coming longer, than he expected; But that he would be in London very shortly. And for my part, (Who at my last Appearing's had not interposed at all to speak, but left all to Mr. Fervacques,) but perceiving my self to be threatned in like manner with Mr. Fervacques by the Company, I desired them to beware, least they repented at leasure; Considering, that I ought to have been discharged for the reasons aforesaid.

Thus having done with the Company at that present, I as yet perceiving no answer from Mr. Cisner to my former Letter, had penned a second in readiness; Intending to deliver it my self to him; Which being profered, Mr. Cisner refused to accept it, saying, he would neither receive any Letter from me, nor give me any answer. Wherefore I applying those uncivill expressions to the Company said, I would open the Letter; and so I did, and left it before them in French; The translated Copy whereof followeth, viz.

body.p:
THe 16th of February I did write to you, desiring you would be pleased to give me satisfaction of that, you told me touching the Law, that it was an Hypocrite, promising that, which it could not perform; And also, that if one was born in the state of Innocencie, as Adam was, and had kept the Law from point to point, nevertheless he could not be saved by it. Sir, I did not doubt, but that you would have sent to mee your Affirmation, proved by the word of God; As every one ought to do, the one to the other; But especially the Ministers of the Gospel, when they have spoken that,
which one doth beleeve to be to the dishonour of God, and contrary to his word. Then I say, one ought in duty to given satisfaction. Saint Paul saith: Wherefore the Law is just, and the Commandment holy, just, and good. It is then no Hypocrite! And Saint Paul saies also, Not the hearers of the Law are justified before God; But the doers of the Law shall be justified; And God saies, Do this and thou shalt live. God is truth it self: God hath spoken it, and will he not do it? God hath promised it, and will he not perform it? Sir, In speaking so lightly of the Law of God, which he pronounced with his mouth, and wrote with his own finger, it is a great sinne. Sir, I hope this will incite you to give me an Answer; And upon which I wait, and rest.

div.p: This Letter being left by me, as aforesaid; And presently afterwards meeting with Mr. D'obey, (one the Elders,) at the Exchange, I desired to know, if the Company had read it; Who replyed, that they had not; But onely he and another of the Consistory had perused it, and put it into the boxe without doing any thing further thereupon. Wherefore I pressed the Company again to read it, by Application to, and by my own Elder, and Mr. La Roche to them made; And therein to order, what should be just, and right: Which being propounded, their Result was, that Mr. Cisner should give me satisfaction, when the matters of the said Accusation (then in difference) were determined between them, and Mr. Fervacques. This Answer being so strange, and egregiously unjust, occasioned, nay indeed necessarily enforced me to dictate another Letter, or Relation to the Consistory, and to present it in person; Which I read to them in the Originall in French; The translated Copy whereof followes in the words hereafter expressed, viz.

body.p: THe Cause of my coming to you at present is, because that to this present, I cannot receive satisfaction from Mr. Cisner, of that he said to me concerning the Law, that it was an Hypocrite, promising that which it could not perform: And he also said, If one was born in the state of Innocencie, as Adam was, and had kept the Law from point to point, yet he should not be saved by it. Sirs, You know the last time, that I was with you here in Consistory, at the end I presented to Mr. Cisner a Letter, and he would not take it, saying also that he would not answer it.

Seeing that therefore, I opened the Letter in your presence, and laid it down before you; hoping that you would have read it, and ordeyned something thereon: but meeting Mr. D'obey on the Exchange, I asked him if the Company had read my Letter: He said, No: but be and another had read it, and put it into the Boxe. Considering, that there was nothing done in that, which so greatly dishonoured God, I thought it was my duty, that by all lawfull means satisfaction might be given. Therefore I desired my Elder Mr. Tainturier, and Mr. La Roche, that they would desire the Company, that they would be pleased to read my Letter, which I directed to Mr. Cisner in the presence of the Company; Seeing that he would not receive it, nor give any anie answer. The Proposition hath been made, and the Companie's Answer was, that there should no Answer be given, till the difference be decided of the Accusation against Mr. Cisner. I have proved the Accusation by Mr. Fervacques, and he maintain's it; And Mr. Fervacques hath proved it by Mr, Doneau, and doubts not, but that he will be here shortly, and
will maintain it to his face. Then it will appear, If Mr. Cisner ha's not held on the part of Mr. D'asigny against his Deputation. Sirs, Seeing that I had proved the Accusation, I am clear from that false imputation of Mr. Cisner; saying, that Mr. Fervacques, and I have invented those lies; And that we were Tellers of lies, and Chiquaneurs. Seeing that it is false, therefore it remaine's, that Mr. Cisner must give me satisfaction of his slander; And in time, and place I shall require it.

Sirs, Me thinks! the reason that you bring for delaying of satisfaction, hath no weight; Because if the Acccusation of Mr. Cisner was true; and that I had inventea it, (as he said,) falsely: Nevertheless in the first place, the Glory of God ought to be more dear to us than our own ho •… urs, nay I say, more dear than our own lives. Therefore (Sirs, •
suffer me to say to you, without offending you, That the office of Ministers and Elders is, aswell to see to the doctrine, as to manners and scandals: And when such doctrine is maintained, that is to the dishonour of God, Then you ought to use the power, that God hath put into your hands for his glory, and to do it in the first place. Sirs, I hope you will not take it in evil, that I do importune you again, seeing it is for the glory of God, and that which I do require of you, ought not to be denied me in good conscience; desiring you, that you would be pleased to take it into your Considerations, and to ordain that which shall be for the glory of God. Attending your answer, I remain,

closer.signed:
Your affectionate servant for
the glory of God.
John Jurin Senior.

div.p:
This Letter, and request being thus read by me to the Consistory, Mr. Stouppe (their President,) without any Methodicall Proposition of a question to the Consistory, or mature deliberation by them upon the Contents thereof; But onely
in an irregular manner did solely of himself propose to me, That if I would promise to submit to that, which they should ordain, they would tell me their result. Whereto I made reply, That I presented my self to the Company, and not particularly to Mr. Stouppe, and it was not for him to give me Answer, before the matter was proposed to the Company, and their advice given thereon: Which at length he acknowledged, desiring me to with-draw, till the business was debated: Which being done, and afterward called in again, Mr. Stouppe said to me, that if I would promise to submit to what they had ordered, They would tell me their Resolution: Otherwise they had nothing to say to me. By which in truth, (As I told the Company) It is evidently demonstrative, that they could sing no other song, but Mr. Stouppe's: Which they rather unworthily preferred to gratifie, than to vindicate the glory of God, so much concerned in the difference: Which was not in my power, nor indeed ought it to be of any other good Christian desired that a business of so great an Importance, and Concernment should be attempted to be buried in forgetfulness: And yet how manifestly, and plainly it may be collected, that by the Companie's Compliance with Mr. Stouppe's Note, they more gratefully designed to conceal Mr. Cisner's offence, and secure him from due Censure and Reproof, than that the glorie and honour of God should be extolled, and advanced, though it was by Mr. Cisner's finall shame, and Reprobation: Which by all true Christians, and pious professors of the Gospel, ought first to be sought, and permitted, rather than that the Majesty of God should be detracted in the least Jod, or tittle of any of his Attributes, or Excellencies. And can there be a greater detraction, and evill speaking, than to undervalue, and disprize the Justice, and goodness of God in giving our forefathers (the seed of Abraham,) so holy, and
just a Rule, Command, and prescription, As he promulged, and published on Mount Sinai, with so much manifestation of his power, and great glory to Moses; So that there was a radiation, and reflection thereof in the very face of Moses; to the great Amazement of the Israelites his brethren. Besides if we consider the equity, and admirable Reason of the Decalogue; And what Testimonie and respect our blessed Saviour gives it in his holy Gospel, that he came not to destroy the Law, but to fulfill it; And from thence doth by way of Exposition, and Illustration, most justly deduce those Exquisite, and most holy morall precepts, and Axioms for the ordering and governing of a Christians life, (As are contained in his Sermon on the mount,) with a sure promise thereunto of eternall salvation; We cannot in reason, or Religion otherwise conclude, then that those Expressions of Mr. Cisner, touching the Law of God, with so much disdeigne, and disestimation, merit, and deserve the detestation, and abomination of all good Christians; And that he ought either publickly to renounce, and disclaim such dangerous, and erroneous Opinions; Or for his pertinacy to be made a publick Example, for the satisfaction of those, that walk worthy of their vocation; and conviction of others, that are, or may be seduced by such evil doctrine, and pernitious Opinions.

Yet notwithstanding, the Consistory answered me that they had nothing more to say to me; unless I would explicitely, and generally submit to them, as aforesaid: And Mr. Stouppe said, that I was a Rebell against the Church, for not submitting to them: Whereto I answered, that I must have of the faith of the Church of Rome to believe, and add faith to that which I did not know; And that I praised God, I was better instructed: And that their office was to satisfie those that desired satisfaction, without binding them to condescend to any thing they did not know: In such manner did this Consistory proceed towards me, as the Bishops heretofore would have done by their Oath ex officio, which they would have imposed on the Clergie with an Et caetera; Binding
them by an Implicite faith to acquiesce in such Canons, as the Convocation should institute, Be they what they would, before they should have known one letter thereof. A design so destructive to the Liberty of a good Conscience! That had it pleased God permissively to suffer it, It would soon have enthralled the godly Ministery of this Land, in a more than Egyptian Bondage: But as God of his infinite mercie suppressed the Authors, and Fomentors of such a mischief complotted against his own Inheritance; So it hath pleased God in this private difference between Mr. Cisner and my self, so farre to disanimate the Monster of that Project, As that it is not to be questioned by a Judicious Reader, but that without an Herculean adventure, if he rightly compare the Circumstances in this Treatise, he may overcome the Hydra of this subject, without a Non obstante, or any other defence or exception.

The said Consistory behaving themselves towards mee in such a partiall, and prejudiciall manner, as before I have related, so that they would not condescend to give me any satisfaction at all. I therefore desired them to resolve mee, what was the Reason, that the Reader in the French Church doth read every Lords day the Ten Commandments, assoon as the Minister is going into the Pulpit, and all the people stand with their hats off, In case that the Law be an Hypocrite? Conjecturing that by this Interrogation, they would have been incited to return mee an answer. But as men affrighted with some sodain, and unexpected Accident, they looked one upon the other, and gave mee not a word of answer. And thereupon I took my leave and departed.

At length being in daily expectation of the coming of Mr. John Doneau, the very Letter it self, (which Mr. Cisner did write to Norwich concerning Mr. D'asigny,) came by Gods good Providence, to the hands of Mr. Fervacques; Wherein he desired the Parties that were engaged with Mr. D'asigny, that
they would be pleased to vouchsafe him a Testimony, that he well behaved himself in his Deputation from our Colloquie. Whereas in truth he was sent down in favour of Mr. De Laune, and his party, against Mr. D'asigny by our Colloquie, with other Deputies, to put in execution the sentence of the Colloquie, against Mr. D'asigny for his obstinacy & unworthiness. And if Mr. Cisner had fairly, and honestly deported himself, according to his charge, It had been most congruous, and proper for him to have sent to Mr. Delaune for a justification, (in whose behalf he was deputed,) then to those who were his adversaries, and under the Censure of the Colloquie. But by the Sequell it will evidently appear, that Mr. Cisner did of set purpose treacherously adhere to Mr. D'asigny, whereby to illude, and frustrate the sentence of our Colloquie against him; And by his perfidious discovery of th • counsells and secrets of the Colloquie, and his fellow Deputies to Mr. D'asigny, render all their Actions, and Designs for the peace of the Church in Norwich, altogether fruitless, and ineffectuall.

Wherefore to proceed in such a Tract, as the necessary Circumstances lead and induce me, I shall acquaint you with the further ill behaviours of the Consistory of London, whereby they might the more facilly prevent the Detection of Mr. Cisner's offence: Which I hope will be constructive, even by the weakest capacity, and apprehension; And manifestly also discover their neglect of Duty and respect to his Highness and the State; To whom they ought with all gratefull submission for their favour, and protection, to render all due obedience, and compliance to all their Acts and Ordinances of State with all readiness, and alacrity.

Then to the matter! On a Saturday night Mr. John Doneau coming to London, Mr. Fervacques gave notice thereof the Lords day following after evening Sermon; And that he would attend the Consistory the Wednesday after, being a Consistory
day. But for asmuch as that a Fast was appointed by his Highness to be kept on Thursday following, (Of which the Consistory, (As they ought to have done,) took no notice at all;) And (as may be conceived probable,) through no good affections to the Observation of, and conformity to his Hignesss's Order, and Appointment, did make no publication on the Lords day before,) The Consistory thereupon afterwards bethinking themselves, (But upon what grounds, is not known, but onely to themselves,) did afterwards order, that each Elder should go in his quarter, and give advertisement to the Members of our Church, that the Sermon, (which of usuall Course, was to have been on the Wednesday,) was put off, and deferred till the Thursday, which was set a part for a Fast, as aforesaid. And Mr. Tainturier (the Elder of Mr. Fervacques,) coming to him, and giving him an intimation according to the said Order, of the Adjournment of the meeting till Thursday, did hereupon inform that Elder, that Mr. Doneau had appointed to be gone out of London towards Norwich on that Thursday morning; For that his business, being very urgent, required him to depart from thence; Desiring Mr. Florantain, that he would be pleased to come that immediate after-noone, and hear what he could say: But he declined so to do; Proposing rather, that some body else might undertake it. Which being related to Mr. Doneau, he said, that through the extremity of his occasions, and affairs, he could not by any means possible stay in London any longer, whereby to attend the Consistory: And therefore that he might declare his Testimony, to as much effect, as lay conveniently within his power, (with respect had to his own private occasions, which he might not in good reason prejudice, being under no Coercive power, but merely in a friendly manner desired to assert, and averre a matter within his own knowledge,) Mr. Doneau did thereupon commit to writing the Relation of his evidence, (As hereafter shall be more expresly, and in terms set forth;) Which he signed, and subscribed with his own proper hand-writing in the
presence of three credible Witnesses, (who have been, and are readie to justifie, and affirm the same to be true;) And delivered it with his subscription to Mr. Fervacques; On purpose that he might present it with all suitable opportunity to the Consistory, for the better manifestation, and confirmation of the truth of his Information concerning Mr. Cisner. And on that Thursday morning Mr. Doneau, having done as aforesaid, went from London on his journey to Norwich.

The same day Mr. Fervacques came to mee, and desired me to accompany him to the Consistory, that we might present to them the Testification of Mr. Doneau: But in regard it was a Fast day, I conceived it not so proper to attend them on such an occasion that day, advising him to defer that affair till the Wednesday after: And moreover Mr. Fervacques on that fast day had given notice to his Elder of the departure of Mr. Doneau from London; And that by reason of his great haste to be at home, he had left the particulars of his knowledge in writing. And when Wednesday was come, We presented our selves to the Consistory, (Mr. Fervacques having delivered into my custody the Originall Letter of Mr. Cisner's before expressed, and keeping to himself Mr. Doneau's Testimony:) Where being come, and notice given of our attendance, the Company called for Mr. Fervacques to come in before them singly: But being they had obliged me at former times equally with him to make proof of the Accusation, I went in with him. No sooner was I before them; But Mr. Stouppe (their President,) desired me to with-draw, saying, they did not call mee in: Whereupon I replyed to them in words, Sirs. It concerne's me, seeing that you would not discharge mee, but have kept mee on this business against all Justice and equity. Upon which the Company said, That if I would not with-draw, they had nothing to say to us: And we might withdraw if we would. Perceiving thus their obstinacie, and perversness I bethought my self, that it was better for mee to withdraw, then not to deliver in to them, what evidence we had
ready against Mr. Cisner: For it was their main design to have taken all advantages against us, whereby they might have prevented the discovery of our proofs against Mr. Cisner: For which they would have gladly taken the occasion from my Refusall to depart out of their presence: And thereupon I withdrew my self. But I pray observe the Indifferencie, and Justice of the Consistory! Who as soon as I was gone out required of Mr. Fervacques to produce the Testimoniall of Mr. Doneau, and Mr. Cisner's own Letter. He told them that I had that Letter; But delivered to them the Originall of Mr. Doneau's subscription, with a Copy thereof; desiring them to compare, and examine them, and to return him the Originall; For that he resolved to keep: Both which Mr. Stouppe receiving and the Company delaying to read, or peruse them, Mr. Fervacques pressed them with much Importunity so to do. But they refused; Resolving, that Mr. Stouppe should compare them privately by himself. Which was so done by them, meerly to surprize Mr. Fervacques, That they might the better keep secret the said Relation of Mr. Doneau, from the Company, As I conceive, or else they would have permitted it to have been read.

Mr. Fervacques hereupon came out from the Consistory, and told mee in what manner they had surprized him: And immediately they called for my self to come in. As soon as I was before them, Mr. Stouppe desired mee to deliver to them Mr, Cisner's Letter. To which I answered, That if they would read it publickly before the Company, I would not onely deliver them the Originall, but a true Copy: But my resolution was, that when they had compared and examined that Copy with the Originall, I should willingly leave that Copy with them; But the Originall I would keep my self. Mr. Stouppe hereupon said to mee, that the Companie had ordered, that he should compare them privately by himself. I replied to him, That my address was to the Company,
and not to himself onelie: And what they required, or had ordered was against the practice of our Government, and the like was never heard of before amongst us: And therefore I would not deliver it in such a manner, nor unless it was read before the Companie. To this Mr. Stouppe returned, That the Companie had not so much time, as to read it. I answered, That could be no excuse; for if one read the Originall, and another took the Copy, It would be done in the tenth part of the time. Hereto Mr. Stouppe gave answer, that if he read the Letter, there would be disputing about it, and they had not time to do it. I made reply, That if that was the true reason, I for my part would promise not to speak one word so as they would presently promise to hear me, and Mr. Fervacques fullie to the matter, before they did proceed to the determination thereof. Which the Company did promise they would do, before they passed their sentence.

Mr. Stouppe hereupon pressed me again to deliver the said Letter, Which I told him, I was resolved not to do, unless it might be publickly read. Wherefore Mr. Stouppe perceiving my Resolution, praied mee, and Mr. Fervacques to with-draw: Which being done, Mr. Stouppe, Mr. Isaac De Lillers, and Mr. D'obey came out of the Consistory to us, and said, that the Company had sent them to read the Letter; Comparing the Copy with the Originall. Wherevpon we manifestly apprehending the unjust, and unreasonable Actions of the Company, which were contrary to all Precedents of times past, and that they had some indirect Design, and ayme in agitation, Whereby to save, and secure Mr. Cisner, from just Censure; But at length discerning no other remedie, We yeilded to those three persons, upon Condition, that before they did proceed in Consistory upon the business, they would hear what we could say: Which they faithfully promised to do, and to grant us suficient time; which then they said they could not set apart. I then delivered them the said Originall, and Copy; They read, and compared them, and returned mee the Originall, Alledging that the matter was of
great consequence, and at that present they could not consider of it. But before they did enter upon it, they would give us notice, and hear what we could say. We referred our selves to their own time,, desiring them in the mean space well to consider of the business, as it was of great Concernment, and with drew.

I question not but the Reader will much admire, why the Company have acted, and mannaged this business contrary to all Rule, Order, and example within the Government of our Churches, and against all equity, and right reason; in stiffling and obstructing the ground and proof of the Accusation against Mr. Cisner, by not permitting them to be publickly read before them. And truely well he may! When as by their partiality, and too much affection to Mr. Cisner, (If ever they did read those particular Charges against him before the Company,) they never did resolve (I doubt) any thing thereupon without his advise; And it is not incompetent in reason to conceive, that he was affraid, that such a positive discovery, and proof of his offence, should be published to the Company, before such time, as that he had instructed, and secured his friends to his advantage, and gained time, and opportunity for them to fitt, and prepare themselves with Arguments, and Expositions, whereby to justifie Mr. Cisner from any Crime, or misdeed, or at least to construe, and interpret it with a more candid, and favourable Representation, then in truth the just merits of his fact do deserve. And as it might have seemed strange to his friends at first; So the Company did take a singular, and remarkable Course, that they shoud never hear of it at all, As farre forth as they could possibly advise, or imagine: Or otherwise they would not have made such strange Resolutions, and orders; As before, and in this Treatise shal be manifested and declared.

But before I shall further impart, and relate to the Reader the Transactions of the Consistory concerning Mr. Cisner, or my self, I hold it requisite to give him a perfect, and exact
Accompt of the miscarriages of Mr. D'asigny; (Whereupon he fell under the Censure and judgement of our Colloquie in the yeer. 1646: which was ordered by them to be put in execution by Mr. Cisner, and others; And which Mr. Cisner for his part onely, did, as much as he could, attempt, (as before is hinted, and insinuated,) to render, and make it of noe purpose, or effect:) As being the originall ground, and occasion of all the ensuing matters herein after contained, with as much brevity, as I can, not abridging the truth.

And now, that the truth of particulars may be the more Methodically understood, I shall acquaint the Reader, that Mr. D'asigny, being in London, and not having any Pastor-ship, or charge in any of the French Churches in England; And being related in so • e kindred or affinity by his wife to Doctor De Laune, (Paster of the French Church in Norwich) went down to Norwich, to give the said Doctor a visit: whither being come, the Doctor received him with much civility, and desired him to preach a Sermon for him to his congregation: which he did with much satisfaction, and content to his Auditory. And after this the said Doctor, being aged, and very sickly was contented, and desired Mr. D'asigny to be helpfull, and assistant to him. Who being once admitted, and received, as a Coadjutor, by the Doctor's Consent, did, not long after so arrogantly, and aspiringly behave himself, as that he endeavoured to lay aside Doctor Delaune's Ministery, and to gain the Church to himself. Which did occasion a debate, and Consideration of the matter by our Colloquie: Who at length for the peace, and quiet of the Church in Norwich, did order, that Mr. D'asigny should be Coadjutor to the Doctor. Mr. D'asigny hereupon having obtained such a foot-step into the Doctor's Church, did so farre insinuate into the affections of the people, as that he made a Rent, and Schisme amongst them so wide, and distant, As that the greater part did ungratefully expell and put out the Doctor, (their ancient Pastor,) out of his Church. So that he was constrained with those, that of duty adhered
to his Ministery, to meet, and assemble together in another place.

Hereupon the Magistrates of Norwich, and the rest of the French Churches, Considering the quality of Mr. D'asigny's Insolency, and Affront done to such an ancient Pastor, as the Doctor was, did assist him in his Application for redress to the Parliament; Who referred his Case, and Grieveance to a Committee: And they upon hearing the particulars thereof transferred the whole business to the decision and determination of the Colloquie, which should next meet, and convene for all our Churches; The Case being more proper for them to resolve, and adjudge according to our own Discipline, and Church Government.

Not long after, viz. 12th of August 1646: A Colloquis of our Churches did assemble in London; And after a full bearing, and serious Consideration of the premisses, (amongst other matters then before them,) did pass this ensuing translated Act from the Originall in French, being the 87th Article of that Colloquie, viz.

This day was present, and the Articles read against Mr. D'asigny, and the daies following examined, and proved: And after serious Consideration of the Discipline, and of all that doth belong to this business, the Company came to a finall Resolution, which was concluded on Munday the 17th of August, as followeth.

div.head: Article. 87.
div.p:
Considering the unruly carriage of Mr. D'asigny to the precedent Colloquie, held in London in May: 1644. (Which then made him worthy of Censure,) and the Continuation of it in an
higher Degree, in continuing to resist all orders, both Ecclesiasticall, & Civill: From whence followed Disorders, factions, and tumults in the Church in the City of Norwich: And above all, shewing himself contumacious against the Colloquie, being formally called, (though all the differences of the said Church of Norwich have been returned by the honourable Committee of Parliament sitting at Westminster, to the determination of the Colloquie; Which also hath been signified unto him;) The Company (after deliberate, and exact Examinations, aswell of all the Acts Authentick, as of the Magistrates, and higher Powers,) in the name, and by the Authority of our Lord Jesus Christ, declare the said Mr. D'asigny to be fallen from the title of Coadjutor, which was by the precedent Colloquie, (for the peace of the Church,) granted to him, and also unworthie of the holy Ministerie in the Church of Norwich: And besides do interdict him the execution of his Ministerie, not onelie in the Church of Norwich, but also in the other Churches that are, or in those that may be of our Colloquie. The which Churches are by this present Colloquie expresly defended from admitting Mr. D'asigny into the exercise of the function of the holy Ministerie. And especially the Church of Norwich is exhorted to put their hands to the execution of this Sentence: So that by that means, they may manifest their desire to continue in the Communion of our Churches, under the Protection of the King and Parliament.

The Colloquie having made this foregoing sentence, did judicicusly consider how it might be put in due execution. And at length they did elect, and choose five persons from amongst themselves to be sent to the Church of Norwich. viz: Mr. Philip Delmey, Pastor of Canterbury, Mr. Cisner Pastor of London, two Elders of London, and one of Canterbury; And all these five persons did fully undertake this their Deputation, promising to do their utmost endeavours, that the said sentence might be put in execution according to the true intent of the Colloquie.

But the Reader shall now most palpably discern, that all the said Deputies, (excepting onely Mr. Cisner,) did, (As by the sequel will appear,) honestly, and justly perform their duties; And that he, (and he onely,) was the man that betrayed his trust; And thereby as far as he could, perfidiously betray all the Churches of the French tongue in England. And this will most exactly be made evident, by the following translation of the Original in French of the Testimony of the said Mr. D'oneau against Mr. Cisner, which was not permitted by the Consistory of London to be publickly read, as is afore-mentioned. Which said Mr. D'oneau was an Elder in the said separated Congregation under Mr. D'asigny from the regular Church under Doctor De Laune in Norwich, And merely for love of the truth hath made the Publication of his knowledge, As followe • h.

I John D'oneau the younger do confess, and declare to whom It may, or might concern, That about seven, or eight years past, When the Deputies of the French Churches of London, and Canterbury, were sent to Norwich, (being lodged at the signe of the Blew-horse,) Mr. D'asigny, and I having had notice thereof, made our Address towards the said place. We sent to Mr. Cisner, (being in Companie of the said Deputies,) praying him to come to speak with some friends, which he did. Then Mr. D'asigny having saluted him, said unto him, That he must declare to Ʋs, all the ground of the business, for which they were Deputies to the Church, and that he should do it without concealing any thing. Whereupon the said Cisner answered, that he could not tarry for two reasons: First, because that he feared, that he should be suspected. Secondlie, that they were then upon the business, for which he was deputed, with other Circumstances: By which we heard, and understood that, which passed in their business, being in the Chamber joyning to theirs, where he left Ʋs, with promise to meet Ʋs on the morrow morning at an house in a place, called Sandling's Lodgings, behind the great Church by the River, (Being a place out of the way,) for fear he should he discovered in our Cempanie.
The which he did, (accordinglie, as he had promised us,) between seven and eight a clock in the morning. Where he continued untill about noone. Assoon as he met at the said place, Mr. D'asigny took Mr. Cisner by the hand and said to him, (Sir,) you must declare to us the ground of your business, for which you are come. He demanded of Mr. D'asigny, What man is that? Ʋpon which he answered, It is one of our friends: Fear not to declare all your business. Whereupon he declared to us manie things, that the Deputies had order to propound to us, to the end to perswade us to yield thereto, (Which would take up too much time to relate.) And said to us that if in Case we would not consent thereunto, They would go by way of the Magistrate to perswade us to yield thereto: But if that would not do, Then that they should endeavour to do it, by way of a Committee. Whereupon there happened other discourse by the said Mr. Cisner; Who told us that we were not obliged to submit our selves; for they had not power to constrain us to do it: Therefore we might keep us to our own Resolutions. This, (as above,) with manie other things, which he declared unto us, was concealed from the rest of the Brethren; fearing least he should be discovered; because if they had been spoken of, we could not have anie more understood the secrets, and that which passed in the Consistory of London, Which the said D'asigny related to me, and told mee, that he understood them from time to time from Mr. Cisner at London, with whom he did correspond. All this above said, although that it be verie true, I had not an intention to declare it; nor have I been required; But understanding the affront, that Mr. Cisner did to Mr. Delmey openlie in the Church, I could not refrain my self to declare this; Which I had resolved to burie for ever.
div.closer:
Written this eight of May. 1655.
Signed John D'oneau the younger.
We under written do certifie, that this is the own writing and Subscription of John D'oneau.
John Causton.
David Dolley.
John Fervacques.

div.p: This Testification I submit to the Judgement, and Construction of the Reader; And now I shall insert the translated Copy of Mr. Cisner's own Letter, which he wrote to Mr. John De Hagen dwelling at Norwich, in French concerning Mr. D'asigny, and the business before intimated, As followeth. viz.

body.p:
ALthough I have not had the honour for to converse with you in particular; Nevertheless the Report that hath been made unto me of your faithfullness, pietie, and sngular affection to the peace of the Churches, doth encourage me to write to you these few Lines, for to tell you my opinion, upon the matter of the Letter, which you have sent for answer unto that of my Church. Certainlie I must avow, that your Consistory, hath had some cause to be discontented for an apparent reproach, that was done to it; In regard that it appeare's by your Letter, the summ, that you contribute unto him for his maintenance, and in doing all you can possible: For as the High Dutch Proverb saith, Where there is nothing, the Emperour himself looseth his right; And that no body is bound to an Impossibility. But if your Consistory take's the pains to consider, that our Letter doth not speak by Affirmation, but onelie by supposition, and report; Which hath been made to us by the Gentlemen, the Brethren of Mr. De Laune, your Minister;
yea who hath caused us to read divers Letters, which do witness his extream povertie; I hope It will make a favourable Construction of our expression, as it is convenient in the meekness of their charitie. In the mean time I pray you, (Sir,) to remember some things, which passed in your Church about seven, or eight years agone. Without doubt you remember, that the late Mr. Delmey, with some Elders were deputed towards your Church, for to deliver unto your Consistory the Sentence of the Colloquie, which was against him, & Mr. D'asigny, (then your Pastour.) Now you all know, how holilie, and justlie I have carried my self in that Deputation, having not sought anie thing, but the good, peace, and edification of your Church; For which I continue my praiers unto God unto this day, as also for the other Churches, without ever to approve of the Instruments of violence, and the presumption of those; who under a pretence to govern the Churches, and to settle good order, do endeavour to bring in a tyrannous Dominion over the Inheritance of the Lord. But it is happened some moneths since after, to have served for an Instrument to reestablish, (By the grace of God,) the peace, and reunitement of the Church of Canterbury: For which all honest men do rejoice; except Mr. Delmey, (heire of his fathers violent passions;) That Satan hath raised me a great persecution, by means of the aforesaid Mr. Delmey, who for the Despight that he hath to see the reunitement of the said Church, makes a new partie upon the ruine of our ancient Divisions: whereof the chief heads are, Mr. John Jurin the elder, and Mr. Daniel Fervacques; who, not contented to persecute me by Back-biting, have moreover reviled me openlie on the Exchange, in charging me to have betrayed the Church of Norwich, in the Deputation above-named; Although that my Conscience doth testifie by the holy Spirit of my Integritie, and that this monstrous Accusation of the Dragon is not onelie false, but ridiculous, and impertinent; Because they pretend the crime to consist in this, that I should have been the Cause of it (As they slander me,) that your Consistory, and Mr. D'asigny have persisted in their disorder, and rebellion. It is so that they speak: who otherwise
without my Counsell, would have submitted themselves to the Colloquie and should have accepted of the sentence: But that your Consistory then (Of which Mr. D'asigny was President,) was the onelie Church of Norwich; From which Mr. De Laune separated, and was followed by some few persons, which might not, nor ought not to attribute to him the Name. How then could I have betrayed the Church; Of which, (According to what my Accusers say,) I was in the same, the Patron, friend, and Advocate. Where is, and what is the monie, that I have received of Mr. De Laune, and of his? What profit and utilitie have I received of your Consistory for this pretended and imagined treason? Where are the enemies, into whose hands I have delivered your Church? What are those mournfull Mischiefs, wherein my Counsell hath precipitated it? What is the revelation of those Admirable secrets, which hath fortified the Conductors in th • Disorders, and the Confusion? Truely as I know not any secret, which hath been committed to me by anie Company or by anie particular person, that may be; So I could not reveal anie secret, as the thoughts, that I had for the Church, were thoughts of peace. Also all the Counsell that I could have given to your Consistory, or to Mr. D'asigny, tended to perswade them to permit me the Pulpit, for to exhort the people to peace, and to dispose the one, and the other to a convenient submission to the first Colloquie ensuing, with express promise, that Mr. D'elmey, and I should do in manner, that the sentence should be suspended, and that their Cause against Mr. De Laune shall be read over again, and examined anew; And that all Justice should be done them, without having anie regard to the Appearance of anie bodie. Nevertheless so it is, that because my Accusers have declared to my Consistory, that they will prove their Accusation by some Witnesses of Norwich; This therefore for fear that my Innocencie may not be made suspected by some false Testimonie, I have thought necessarie, most humbly to beseech you to do me the favour for to confer with your brethren, that then, (when I was in your Citie,) were in office, aswell of the Elders, as Deacons; Praying them instantly in my name to send me an
Attestation, subscribed by them; In which it shall please them to give Testimonie to my Innocencie, and faithfulness: To the end by this means, untruth may have it's mouth shut. In doing this you shall acquit your Conscience, you shall aide the truth, exercise your Charity towards a faithfull servant of God, and shall oblige my Church, and me in particular for to pray to the Lord for your Prosperitie Corporall and spirituall: Seeing that I am, in expecting the Answer of your good grace, (after having recommended you to the saving grace of God. Sir, and most dear Brother.
body.closer:
Your most humble, and most affectionate
Brother, and servant.
Signed.
Cisner. Superscribed.
To Mr. John De Hagen dwelling at Norwich.

div.p: I shall not need here to Paraphrase, or make any Exposition, or Commentary upon either the Testimony of Mr. Doneau, or Mr. Cisner's Letter, as might well be expected: But for as much as I delivered to the Consistorie in person my Observations and consequent Deductions from the very matter and words themselves according to plain, and Grammaticall Construction, upon and from the things themselves, I shall refer the Reader to the Consideration thereof; As he shall herein after find them particularly set forth. And now I shall proceed to declare the further Injustice, and partiality of the Consistory; Which the Reader may be pleased to observe, As the subject matters fall worthily under, and are submitted to his judgement, and Interpretation.

Having delivered the Copies of Mr. D'oneau's Testimony and Mr. Cisner's Letter to the Consistory as aforesaid, Mr. Fervacques, and my self did, (As well we might,) expect that the Consistory would have appointed us a time, (according to their promises,) to hear what we could further say or alledge against Mr. Cisner: Which if they had done, had been but common and ordinary Justice, and no more, than in honesty they ought to make good their promises: But as a clear and absolute violation and breach of both, and thereby of all requisite Civility, and humanity, they without ever calling us before them or giving us any notice, proceeded to a finall Determination, and Conclusion of the business; Acquitting Mr. Cisner from being guiltie of anie thing whatsoever, even of the least suspicion; And ordered Mr. Delmey to come to me, and Mr. Fervacques, and acquaint us, that they had considered of our accusation against Mr. Cisner, and passed their Judgement of Acquittall; Desiring him to perswade with us to submit, and yeild quietlie thereunto. And for the peace of the Church, all things should be buried, and forgotten: Which Message Mr. Delmey delivered to me, and as they requested him, he desired me to go to Mr. Cisner, and reconcile my self to him: But the news being so strange, and without Comparison, I wondred much at Mr. Delmey, that he should undertake to be the Reporter of it, and indeed I was displeased with him, for giving any Colour to such Injustice.

Hereupon Mr. Fervacques, and my self went to our Elder Mr. Florantine Tainturier, Signifying to him our Admiration, and Amazement, that the Consistorie should so lightly regard their reiterated promises to hear us before their Sentence given upon the matter: And that if we had lived amongst Heathens, they would not have dealt so unjustly with us; And hereupon we pressed him, That he would move the Company to hear us: Who did present our desires to them; And they returned answer, that they would hear us, and give notice to us when we should attend them. Which afterwards they did;
And we appeared before them: But instead of hearing us openly in the Consistorie, Mr. Stouppe and some four or five more of the Companie desired us to go up with them into the Library: Whither being come Mr. Stouppe said, that it was necessary to think of some waies of Reconciliation; For they saw that the divisions increased in the Church; We answered, that it was our desire, upon a just and right ground. Mr. Stouppe demanded, what was our just, and right ground. We replyed, that we left it to the Consistory to propound to us; And if we found it for the glory of God, and the good of the Church, we should accept it. Hereupon Mr. Stouppe asked me, If I would acknowledge Mr. Cisner to be an honest man. I thereunto answered, that If I should so do, my Conscience would tell me, that I did lie. Wherefore Mr. Stouppe said that they would take it into Consideration, and we should hear from them: And so we parted. I expected from this Answer, that the Consistory would have advised, and considered of a way, to settle us in peace, and made some proposition to us; But they never did. By which it may well be concluded, that this was merely a Stratagem of Mr. Stouppe's to have drawn us to an acknowledgement, that Mr. Cisner was an honest man, and so we should thereby have condemned our own selves. At length I having penned a Letter, and made some observations on Mr. D'oneau's Testimony, and Mr. Cisner's Letter, (which by reason of my hopes to receive the said Propositions, though readily prepared, I deferred to present;) And the Consistorie sending to me, and Mr. Fervacques to come and declare what we had against Mr. Cisner, We thereupon appeared; And then I read this ensuing Letter to them in French, presenting the Reader with the Translation thereof, as followeth.

body.p:
LAtely you were pleased to send unto me Mr. Delmey, for to persuade me to reconcile my self with Mr. Cisner. By that it seems unto me, that you do not hold me discharged of that I have said of Mr. Cisner. Sirs, It seems unto me, that I have justified my self from what Mr. Cisner imputed unto me, because that I have produced from whom I had it, and that he doth acknowledge to have told it me; so that he doth justifie me, that I am not the Inventor of it. And I say, I am no Inventor of Lies, nor a Chiquaneur, as Mr. Cisner imputed to me before you. Sirs, seeing that you do not hold me discharged, I am resolved, (by the Grace of God,) to justifie my self; for I will not betray my Innocency to cover the Hypocrisie, and unfaithfulness of another. Therefore we delivered on the 16th of May unto the Consistory, the Testimonie of Mr. Doneau against Mr. Cisner, signed before witnesses and also the Letter of Mr. Cisner, which he wrote unto those, that held with Mr. D'asigny, for to obtain from them a Testimonie to justifie him.
