It seems unto me, that both the above-said do prove amply, and clearly, that Mr. Cisner hath betrayed the Church of Mr. De Laune, and also the Colloquie; and spake unworthily of them in outragious language. If this be suffered; where is our Government? In this he hath done more, than ever the Bishops did in time past; for I have not heard, that they did so vilifie such an Assembly, and spake unworthily of the dead, and of the living. Sirs, I hope that you have read the Testimony of Mr. Doneau, and Mr. Cisner's Letter in the presence of all the Company; although you would not suffer it then to be read, but that Mr. Stouppe must read it by himself. This hath not been the practice of the times past. Sirs, me thinks! to clear the things before you, it is needfull, that I do repeat unto you the beginning of this difference; for when you called me first before you, you would not suffer me to
declare it, but Mr. Stouppe interrupted me, and said, To the fact, To the fact! so that I was not permitted to relate it. And now it is necessarie to give you a true Relation of what passed: I seeing Mr. Cisner, and Mr. La Roche walking together on the Exchange, I resolved with my self to speak with them, to see if I could do something to allay the new begun differences, touching the Sermon of Mr. Delmey upon the 21th Section of the Catechisme, concerning Repentance. At the verie instant, Mr. Fervacques came to me, and I told him, what I intended to do, in speaking with those Gentlemen, and to cast water upon the fire begun, and not oile, and that I was resolved not to speak any thing, that might give just offence. So we went unto them, and having saluted them, I said (Sirs) I am verie sorrie to understand; that new differe • ces have arisen in the Consistory, upon the Sermon of Mr. Delmey, on Repentance. Mr. La Roche said, his business called him away, so that he could not stay any longer, and so took his leave, and away he went. I said unto Mr. Cisner, that I did hear Mr. Delmey, and in my judgement, that which he preached was sound and Orthodox, and according to the word of God: he told me, his Doctrine was sound: Then I said unto him, why have you made such a severe Act against him? he said because that he had preached against Mr. Stouppe. I asked him, if Mr. Stouppe had preached the Truth: he said, yes; Then I said, if both of them have preached the Truth, then I see no just ground for such a severe Act of sentence against him. I prayed him to tell me, wherein he did fail: he said in the manner: I asked him in what: he thereupon became angry, and said that Mr. Delmey and his party troubled the Church: I prayed him not to keep up the names of parties in the Church; for so long as they retain names in the Church, it is to uphold parties, and that ought not to be in the Church of God; for they ought to be, (as it were,) but one Soul, as they be but one Bodie. Mr. Cisner seemed to maintain it, for he produced that Passage of the Corinthians, and said, that there was for Paul, and Cephas, nea, and a party for Christ. Ʋpon that I asked him, if the Corinthians were praised for it, or reproved; he said, Reproved.
Then I said, seeing they were Reproved, we ought not to retain names, and praied him, that he would not use it so often, as he did use to do: And further told him, that I had heard that he had preached of the Hypocrisie of the Law: saying that I thought, that he had not preached it, but that there was some mistake, and that he was not well understood. Then he told me, that he had preached something like it, and also said that the Law was an Hypocrite, promising that, which it could not give, or perform; and that more over, if any one was born in the estate of Innocencie, as Adam, and had kept the Law from point to point, and fulfilled it, yet he could not have been saved by it. I told him, that Doctrine was very strange Doctrine, and that I was very much unsatisfied to hear such Doctrine from him. He said to me, it may be you are ignorant, and do not unders • and what is Hypocrisie. I did Confesse that I was ignorant, but my desire was to learn. And then he began to say, that there were Two sorts of Hypocrisie, and proceeded no further; but was angrie, and said, that it was I, and my partie, that troubled the Church. I thereupon said, no not I! nor those you call my partie! But it is of the partie, that was sent unto Norwich for the peace of the Church, and betraied it: He told me, that I did lie, and all those that did say it. I replied to him, if the thing be proved, who then will be the Liar? and upon that we separated. This is a true narration of the things that passed, to the best of my Memory, and I do believe, that Mr. Cisner cannot say the Contrarie, if he will speak the truth. Sirs, I do desire you to Judge, who gave the first offence, for he said that it was I, and my partie; Sirs I would know of him, or of the Companie, how I could have an hand, or had any thought to have made this difference, upon the Sermon of Mr. Delmey concerning Repentance. I say, if I would have done it, it was not in my power to have done it; for the difference was between Mr. Delmey and the Consistory; so that I could not have an hand in it, because that I am not of the Consistory, and for that I answered unto Mr. Cisner, that it was of the partie, that were sent unto Norwich for the peace of the Church, but betraied it;
There were Five Gentlemen in the Company; but. Mr, Cisner took it onelie to himself, when it was spoken of the Company. Which shewed plainly to me, that Mr. Cisner's Conscience reproved him, or otherwise he would not have taken it unto himself. If he had asked me of whom I did speak it, I would have told him, that it was himself onely, and not any of the others; because I am assured, that all of them did their duties according to their Deputations, and onely Mr. Cisner did deal with Mr. D'asigny, against whom he was sent: And to do that, without the advice, and approbation of his brethren, (the Rest of the deputies,) and after that, Mr. Cisner had private Communication with Mr. D'asigny, and declared it not to the rest of the Deputies! If there was nothing else, but that against Mr. Cisner, it were enough to make him to be suspected, that the thing is true: But it is declared sully by Mr. John Doneau, that he did give Counsell to Mr. D'asigny not to submit to the sentence, for that they had no power to constrain them. If that be not to betray, then I think there can be no treachery? And by his own Letter he acknowledgeth to have held the part of Mr. D'asigny; which is against his deputation: And his own Testimony is more worthy to add faith unto, then all the Witnesses, that can be brought to the contrary. I will not insist any longer upon the particularities of it, because that I do here present unto you some Observations, that I have made upon both the abovesaid: and I doubt not, but it will be manifestly proved, that I have not invented this accusation; But it is the good Providence of God, that hath brought these things so farr, and so to discover those things, that have been so long hid: for I say, I had no intention to have declared it: But he laid upon me such a false thing so that I could not contain my self, but spake, that which I have heard; for it came forth without my thinking of it. Sirs, I do desire you well to consider the sentence of the Colloquie, that is against Mr. D'asigny, and also the Commission given to the Deputies, to put the sentence in execution; and then consider the Testimony of Mr. Doneau, and principally Mr. Cisner's own Letter, and well weigh and deliberate them in the fear of God, and then Judge of them, according
as the things do appear, & that every one may bear his own burthen, and he that hath done amisse, acknowledge his fault: And in so doing, God will be glorified, and by that means the peace of the Church will be setled; for which I pray; and desire, that peace, and Truth may imbrace each other. Sirs, I am yet waiting for satisfaction with impatience, touching the saying of Mr. Cisner, concerning that which he said to me of the Law. I say, I do hold him to be a Blasphemer, or an Atheist, untill he doth prove his saying, or explain it; or that he doth acknowledge his fault to God by true Repentance, for his evill speaking of God, and his Law; It seems to me, that it ought not to be so long time delayed in waiting for it. I remain.

closer.signed:
Your affectionate servant, who
desires to maintain the Truth.
John Jurin Senior.

div.p: The reason why, I did not make any mention in the abovesaid Letter of their unjust proceedings, was, because that I would not incense them, hoping that they would have considered it better, and so to have done justly.
Here followe the Observations, that I delivered, and were read before the Company.

TO build well upon any thing, is to lay a sure foundation. The ground of this dispute, that is befallen between me, and Mr. Cisner, is upon the matter of the Colloquie, held in London in August, 1646. in the Article. 87: where it is said, that Mr. D'asigny is unworthy of the Ministery in the Church of Norwich, and besides he is interdicted the execution of it, not onely in the Church of Norwich, but also in all the others, that are, or that may be
of the Colloquie; who expresly defended them from admitting the said D'asigny in the execution of the Function of the Holy Ministery: Mr. Cisner and the Deputies, that were sent unto Norwich to put in execution this sentence, undertook to do their duties therein; And I am fully satisfied, that all the Deputies did their duties, except onely Mr. Cisner, who did the contrary, as by the Testimony of Mr. John Doneau; and also as it doth appear by Mr. Cisner's own Letter, which sheweth plainly, that he did not his dutie, as he had undertaken to do, but betraied the Cause, which he was sent to maintain; As it will be manifest by the Observations following.

div.head: Observations on the Testimony of Mr. John Doneau Juuin • , against Mr. Cisner.
div.p: 1. Assoon as the Deputies were arrived in Norwich, Mr. D'asigny, and Mr. Doneau went to their Lodging, and then sent for Mr Cisner, and he came to them into the Chamber next to theirs: And having saluted M. Cisner, said unto him, you must declare to us all the grounds of your business, without concealing any thing. This shews clearly, that Mr. D'asigny, and Cisner kept Correspondency together, seeing that Mr. D'asigny spake so freely to Mr. Cisner; and it also shews the Testimony of Mr. Doneau to be true.

2. Mr. Cisner answered, that he could not tarry, for two Reasons: First, because that he feared he should be suspected; Secondly, that they were then upon the business, for the which they were deputed; but he promised them to meet them on the morrow morning, at an house in a place, called Sandling's behind the great Church by the River, being a place out of the way, for fear that he should be discovered. If Mr. Cisner in so doing, had done nothing but his duty, he had no need to fear his
being discovered: But his Conscience reproved him, and this shews, that this his dealing was not lawfull, but contrary to, and against his Deputation.

3. That Mr. Cisner left Mr. D'asigny, and Mr Doneau in the next Chamber, joyning to theirs, where they did hear, and understand all that they debated; and neverthelesse Mr. Cisner did not give any notice of it to the Company. This was to betray the Company, and their affairs.

4. Mr. Cisner according to his promise met them at the abovesaid place, between seven and eight of the clock in the morning, and continued with them till above Twelve at noone; and discovered to Mr. D'asigny, and Mr. Doneau all the Resolutions of the Deputies and counselled Mr. D'asigny, and Mr. Doneau not to submit for they had no power to constrain them to do it. If this be not betraying, there can be none in Church affairs? But it appears that he hath betrayed, for these three Reasons.

list.item: 1. First, because he had no Commission to treat with them by himself, (I say,) with Mr. D'asigny, who was under the Censure, and sentence of the Colloquie.

2. Mr. Cisner was sent with the other Deputies; And so he ought not to have treated without their Advice, and approbation; neverthelesse he hath discovered all their businesse to those, against whom they were deputed.

3. He counsell's them not to submit, for they had no power to constrain them. Is not this to betray, by giving such Counsell to Mr. D'asigny? seeing that Mr. Cisner had undertaken to
pursue the sentence of the Colloquie; yet neverthelesse he counselled them not to submit: And whither this is not to betray, I think no man will question.

div.p: 5. We may observe the great Providence of God in discovering that, which hath been kept so long secret; Considering what Mr. Doneau, saith, Although the abovesaid be very true, I had no intention to declare it, nor have been required, but understanding the affront, that Mr. Cisner did to Mr. Delmey openly in the Church, I could not refrain my self to declare this, which I had resolved to bury for ever. God is just, and doth discover in his good time the wickednesse of persons, and their unjust Actions.

div.head: Observations on the Letter of Mr. Cisner, which he did write to obtain Testimony to justifie himself.
div.p: 1. The first Observation is, that he wrote to Mr. D'asigny, who was under the Sentence of the Colloquie, which judged him unworthy of the Holy Ministery in all the Churches of the Colloquie: Also he wrote to the Elders, and Deacons, that were in office with D'asigny, when the Deputies were at Norwich, to put in execution the sentence of the Colloquie against Mr. D'asigny. Mr. Cisner also wrote to them to obtain a Testimony from them to justifie him against the accusation. If Mr. Cisner would have justified himself to have done his duty, according to his deputation, he ought to have written to Mr. De Laune, and his partie, in favour of whom he was sent. He hath received Testimony from D'asigny, and his partie, against whom he was sent. Which shew's evidently that he hath held with the partie of Mr. D'asigny against his deputation; and so it proves the Testimony of Mr. Doneau to be very true.

2. He flatter's those Gentlemen to obtain a Testimony from them, and blame's the Consistory of London, saying, I must avow that your Consistory hath had some Cause to be discontented for an Apparent reproach, that was done to it. It is to be considered, if Mr. Cisner did not dictate the Letter, and neverthelesse laye's the blame on the Consistory. Is not that Hypocrisie?

3. He doth incourage them not to contribute more, than the summe that they do allow for his entertainment, in doing all you can possible: for as the high Dutch Proverb saith, Where there is nothing, the Emperour himself looseth his Right. If we should do the same to Mr. Cisner, It would not be well pleasing to him; but would be the just Law of Retaliation, to do to him, as he doth counsell those Gentlemen against Mr. De Laune, their ancient Pastor.

4. Mr. Cisner doth acknowledge, that the sentence was against their Consistory, and Mr. D'asigny, their Pastor. Now ye all know, how holily and justly I have carried my self in that deputation, having not sought any thing, but the good, and peace, and edification of your Church. This doth Confirm the Testimony of Mr. Doneau; And the Testimony of Mr. Cisner against himself is more Authentique, than all the Testimonies, or witnesses, that might be brought to the contrary. So that there is Two witnesses to prove the Accusation, viz. Of Mr. Cisner against himself, and that of Mr. Doneau proves clearly, that Mr. Cisner hath betrayed the Church of Mr. De Laune, in maintaining Mr. D'asigny contrary to his deputation.

5. He calls the Colloquie Instruments of violence, and scoff's at the presumption of those, who under a pretence to govern the Churches, and to settle good order, do indeavour to
bring in a Tyrannicall dominion over the Inheritance of the Lord. Is not this the greatest defamation (that can be,) of the Colloquie? and thereby shewes his hypocrisie, perfidiousnesse, and unfaithfulnesse; having undertaken the Commission of the Colloquie with the other Deputies, and neverthelesse speakes so wickedly of them. Then it is no marvell that he hath so betraied them, seeing that he speakes so unworthily of them!

6. He speakes unworthily of Mr. Delmey, who is with God: When as the Divel, and Michael (the Archangel) disputed about the bodie of Moses, the Angel himself durst not bring any railing accusation; but Mr. Cisner dares speak unworthilie of the faithfull servant of God deceased. Which shewe's the hatred, and rancor that is in the heart of Mr. Cisner. It would be well to be satisfied by Mr. Cisner, if such expressions, (Calumniatory,) be a mark of a true Minister of Jesus Christ!

7. He speakes unworthilie of his Fellow-Minister Mr. Delmey (Inheritor of the violent passions of his father,) that Satan hath raised me a great persecution by that means. The Scripture called it persecution, when one is persecuted for maintaining the Truth: but it hath not been heard, that there hath been any debate for anie Truth: but if one be prosecuted for unfaithfulnesse, It is a just Reward of his merit, as this is on Mr. Cisner, for betraying the Cause, which he undertook to maintain. And Sirs, you may very well remember, what imprecations Mr. Cisner made before you in the Consistory touching this businesse!

8. He saith of me, and Mr. Fervacques, (who not content to persecute me by back-biting, &c.) Whereto, The observation of the Precedent Section may serve for the answering thereof. But for his venomous, and aspersing tongue, Its hoped, that the Consistory will do justice, seeing the Thing is so clearly proved,
by Mr. Doneau, and also by his own Letter: By which it appears plainly, and manifestly, that he hath taken Mr. D'asigny's part, directly against his deputation; which justifie's us that we have not invented it, and are not Tellers of lies, nor Chiquaneurs, as Mr Cisner termed us before the Consistory. And therefore he ought to prove his saying, or acknowledge his fault.

9. He saith, seeing that your Consistory, (then upon the which Mr. D'asigny was President,) was the onely Church of Norwich; from which Mr. De Laune separated, and was followed by some few persons, who might not nor ought to attribute to him the name, &c. Gentlemen, I desire you will consider well and deliberately this Particular, comparing it with the sentence of the Colloquie, which condemne's Mr. D'asigny, and judgeth him unworthy of the holy Ministery in the Churches of the Colloquie; the said Colloquie justifying Mr. De Laune. Neverthelesse Mr. Cisner condemne's Mr. De Laune, and saies, (followed with some who might not and ought not to attribute the name: Is not this to condemn Mr. De Laune, and his partie, and justifie Mr. D'asigny, and his partie, quite contrary to his Commission and Judgement of the Colloquie? So that it doth verifie the Testimony of Mr. Doneau; And Mr. Cisner by his own Letter maintains to have betrayed Mr. De Laune, and his Church, which was acknowledged the Church of Norwich by the Colloquie: And therein he hath betrayed the Colloquie, which represents all our Churches; but especially our Church of London, who have been at so great Charges for that journey: which in all justice, and equity Mr. Cisner ought to repay.

10. He saith, how could I have betrayed the Church, of the which, (according to my Accusers,) I was in the same the Patron, friend, and Advocate. In this he doth say very true, and I beleeve it. He saith, that I and Mr. Fervacques have said it, when
as we have not said it, nor ever thought to have done so; but his own Conscience say's it, and testfie's it, that he is the patron, friend and Advocate; and so he goes on vaunting, and discovering himself, what he is; and without doubt, he thought, that this Letter should never have been discovered, and come to light: But by the good providence of God it is come to Light, whom it hath pleased, that it should be made manifest to the world for a lively Testimony against him.

11 He saie's, truely as I know not any secret, which hath been committed to me by any Company, or by any particular person that may be, so I could not reveal any secret. Any man may easily judge of the falsenesse of his saying, who hath never so little Judgement, or reason, seeing that he makes no more Conscience in writing. Whereby it may be concluded, that he had the same Conscience to betray the Church, and the Cause, which he had undertaken to have maintained, according to his deputation, and may aswell justifie himself not to have betrayed his Trust, as he doth justifie himself, that he knows no secrets committed to him.

12. He promised, that Mr. Delmey, and himself would do in manner, that the sentence should be suspended, and that their Cause against Mr. De Laune should be read over again, and examined, and that all justice should be done them, without having regard to the appearance of any body. If he had any such Commission, he would do well to produce it, to make his saying appear to be true. But in so doing he doth in effect condemn the very Colloquie, not to have judged justly.

13. He is afraid, that his Innocency may not be made suspected by some false Testimony. The Truth is, he is afraid, that
the truth should be known. But God hath been pleased, that the truth should be manifested clearly, and that by Mr. Cisner's own Letter. So that it is evident that Mr Doneau's Testimony is also very true, that Mr. Cisner hath upheld Mr. D'asigny, against his deputation, from the Colloquie. And in that which Mr. Cisner thought to have saved himself, he is so firmly, and positively taken, that he cannot find out a way to escape. God is just, and will give to every one, accordingly as they have done.

I desire the Reader to take notice of the later part of my Letter, preceeding my aforesaid Observations, How I charge Mr. Cisner, for that he hath spoken against the Law, and do hold him to be a Blasphemer, or an Atheist, untill he doth prove his Saying, or acknowledge his fault to God, by true Repentance; And neverthelesse I could not receive from the Consistory, or Mr. Cisner any answer to this day, either to prove it by the word of God, or to deny it.

Now after all the aforesaid severall Observations, made by me, were read in the Consistory, Mr. Cisner made a Reply thereunto, but with so many falsities, and impudent untruths, that they were in no wise beseeming the profession of one, that pretends to know, that there is a God, and that he is just, and will give to every one, according to his works: And in truth were such, as that neither my self, nor Mr. Fervacques could with patience hear him, and forbear to refute, and convince him. But the Company desired us to be patient, till they had done; And then we should say, what we pleased. Upon which their promise we rested satisfied, till Mr. Cisner had concluded. And then we desired to reply to his falsities. But Mr. Stouppe said in a deriding manner, It could not be done, before that he had asked the Companies Advise. Which I said was his duty to do; And upon his request we with-drew, waiting for the Companies result.

A while after we were called before the Company, who said, that they had considered of the matter; But did not find Mr. Cisner Guilty of that, wherewith we had charged him. However for the peace of the Church, all things passed should be buried under foot, and forgotten: desiring us to go to Mr. Cisner, and reconcile our selves to him.

It is fit I should give you some accompt, who at this present, (when this sentence was passed,) were Members of the Consistory of London, Because very ordinarily every six moneths some of the Elders go out, and others come in. Wherefore the Pastors were Mr. Delmey, Mr. Stouppe, and Mr. Cisner. The Elders were Mr. Florantine Tainturier, Mr. Samuel Vincent, Mr. James Ʋancourt, Mr. Isaac De Lillers, Mr. Isaac Vanney, Mr. David Bouquet, Mr. Peter La Roche, Mr. James De Quen, Mr. Deriek 〈◊〉
M •…
Peter Rouseau, Mr. Peter Bar, Mr. Paul D'obey, & Mr. Peter Caulier. Which three last mentioned persons, being (as well may be supposed) deluded and seduced by Mr. Cisner and Mr. Stouppe, have been with them the grand disturbers of our Churches peace, and the Conductors in, and Fomentors of all the troubles, that have befallen it, as I do probably conjecture. And yet Mr. Cisner hath had the Confidence to retort upon us, That it was we that had betraied the Church: Which scandalous Aspersions the Consistory would never, (though often intreated by us,) order him to prove against us; or give us any satisfaction for, or vindication against it. For which grand Injustice, and partiality there is none I hope, but of merit, and desert not will condemn and reprove them.

Thus having discovered the persons and their unjust Actions, I shall proceed to give you a further Accompt of my self and Mr. Fervacques: Who, assoon as we heard Mr. Stouppe pronounce the said unheard of and unjust sentence, Did instantly protest against the same as unequall, and appealled from it, and them to the next Colloquie, to whom: we would submit and desired
the Company to take notice of our Appeal, and enter it in their Books; For that they had dealt with us falsely, deceitfully, and wickedly: For having justified Mr. Cisner in all his wickednesses, they thereby had made his sins their own, for which they must one day give an Accompt. And upon this we desired them, since our divisions were so great, to he pleased to call a Colloquie for the appeasing, and reconciling thereof. They said they would consider of it, and give us Answer in due time. But hearing nothing from them Mr. Fervacques and my self went to our Elder desiring him to propound it in the Consistory, that a Colloquie might be called. He did so, and returned us their Answer, That Mr. Cisner being out of town and-till he returned they could give us no answer. Shewing plainly, that they cannot do any thing without him. I thereupon replied to our Elder, that they ought to do it; without Mr. Cisner for if he and his friends could hinder it, We should not have a Colloquie in their daies.

At Mr. Cisner's return, We went to the Consistory, and after long attendance were called in: We told them, we came to know their Resolutions for the calling the Colloquie. They desired us to with-draw, and we should have their Answer; But instead thereof, they at the last did arise in a Confusion. Wherefore seeing them come out one after another, and one of them crying out, he would come no more amongst them, I said to Mr. D'obey, What? Have you, made us stay thus long, and now give us no Answer! He returned, that we should have it at the Exchange. To which I said, that if that were their answer, we would come to them, when they were in better order. And then he told me, that Mr, Delmey would give us the Answer. Who coming out said, that the Companies Resolution was to stay the ordinary time of the Colloquie.

A moneth, or two after my Appeal made as aforesaid, my Elder brought me my Token for the Sacrament of the Lords Supper: But for that we somuch pressed the Companie for a Colloquie,
they seemed to be angry, and that to be revenged on us, they would keep us from the Sacrament. And the second or third month after my Elder said to me, that he had order to keep back my token, till I did reconcile my self to Mr. Cisner. I asked him If I had committed any thing since my Appeal, that made me unworthy. For that having made an Appeal, all things ought to remain, as they were, till they we • e decided in Colloquie. And being I was not kept from the Sacrament before my Appeal made, nea, not the first or second moneth after it, I therefore ought not at all to be debarred from it, especially not having committed anie fact after my said Appeal, which did anie waies render me unworthy or disabled. And this is according to the Act of our eighth Colloquie, in the year 1589. in the words ensuing, viz.

div.head: Article, the 8th.
div.p: No appeal shall be received, before that the sentence be pronounced by the Consistory: Which in Case of an Appeal, shall stand intirely untill it be fully decided by the Colloquie. Ʋnlesse that the Delinquent shall desist from his Appeal, and satisfieth the Consistory.

After this on a Lords day in the evening Mr. Stouppe, Mr. Bar, and Mr. La Roche came to my house to persuade me to reconcile my self to Mr. Cisner. I took it as a Complement from them, and said, I was ready to do it, when he had given me satisfaction, and not before. Mr. Stouppe replyed that I ought to do it, and that by dispute he would convince anie man that I ought so to do. To which I said, that I accepted of a Dispute: But he made me no answer. I therefore further objected, that if he was a man of his word, he would be as good as his word? Whereto he answered, that he could not undertake it without the consent of the Consistory. By which I perfectly discerned, that it was but a mere Ostentation and Uaunting in Mr. Stouppe; naked words, without
deeds; and in fine and Ayery, empty Complement, whereby to sound and fathom my Inclination; For ever since I have heard no more of it. At that time Mr. Stouppe acknowledged, that Mr. Cisner had preached against the Law; And had compared it to a Diall, that marks Twelve, and stricke's six; saying, Is not that an Hypocrite? And also Mr. Stouppe said, that Mr. Cisner compared the Law to a squint eyed man, seeming to look one way, and indeed looke's another: Further saying, Is not that Hypocrisie?

Our Divisions encreasing more and more, Mr. Fervacques and I did hold it our duties to use all lawfull means for the determination thereof; And therefore presented our selves to the Consistory, for that they held not fit to call a Colloquie till the ordinary time, as is before mentioned, Desiring them in the mean time to call a Classis to prevent the further growth of our differences. They thereupon desired us to with-draw. And afterward calling us in again said, that they found not such a word in the Discipline, as a Classis, and that it was an Innovation: And therefore they were resolved to stay the ordinary time for a Colloquie. Mr. Stouppe being asked by me, when that time would be, said about nine or ten moneths hence. I replyed to him, that I conceived it was more, If they had not altered the time, For a Colloquie was to be every three years; But he affirmed, in every two years. However we wondred at their term of Innovation, in respect of a Classis. Saying, they could not be so ignorant in our government, For that Mr. Cisner knew full well, that himself had been at a Classis; But I perceived, they desired to defer the business, and not to come to the Touch-stone, as not willing to, or brooking a triall, and examination thereof.

We further desired the Consistory to inform us, for what reason, they did keep back our Tokens. They said, Because we would not reconcile to Mr. Cisner. We answered, that they well knew, that some time past we offered to do it upon good and just grounds;
referring it to themselves to propound them which; they had never yet done: But that now having made our Appeal to the Colloquie, all proceedings for that businesse ought to rest as it was, when we appealed, till it was ended by the Colloquie. For that, to proceed after an Appeal made, was to usurpe that power, which the Consistory ought not. And so it was tyranny and oppression in them to proceed against any one for the same fact, for which he had appealed, And they could not with hold our Tokens, unlesse we had committed something since our Appeal, which made us unworthy: Which we demanded of them to prove and make to appear: Or else they had no ground for their Actions: Which we verily beleeved they had not: Thereby fully discovering their Iniquity and injustice in not discharging the duties of their Elder-ships, having admitted Mr. Cisner notwithstanding his wickedness, and that he hath not a •… given satisfaction for his Atheisticall, and erroneous Doctrine, and treacherous dealings so apparently detected, and proved against him: And because they justified him, and held communion with him, protecting him from due triall, and Censure, we thereupon with-drew.

Considering the premisses, And that we had so fully proved the Accusation against Mr. Cisner, Mr. Fervacques, and I being as aforesaid in the Consistory, demanded of them, that satisfastion should be given us by Mr. Cisner for his slandering of us before them, which they might well remember, since with such Imprecations he had called God, and the holy Ghost to witnesse, that the Accusation was false, and that we had invented it, And were iuventors of Lies, and Reporters of Lies, and Chiquaneurs and also for his slandering and scandalizing us in his Letter to the Gentlemen at Norwich. We therefore desired the Company to do us justice, either that Mr. Cisner might prove his saying, or acknowledge his fault; Who answered, that if we would reconcile our selves to Mr. Cisner, they would then do that, which was reason.

The Members of the Church at length perceiving the Consequence of the business, with much Importunity pressed the
Elders to call a Colloquie: Who finding themselves thus sollicited, gave out to the people, that if we would defray the Charges of the Deputies of the Churches, We then should have a Colloquie. Which Report being made to me, I went to my Elder and desired to know, if it were true; who said, it was so: I asked, if there was no hinderance, but want of money; he replied, there was not; And that if I would undertake to pay the Charges, we should have one speedilie. I desired him to propound to the Company, that I would undertake to pay the Charges, so as the Colloquie might be called suddainlie before the winter. Which proposition he made: But the Company found out evasions still to put off the Colloquie. And therefore I wrote to them in French, the translation whereof followeth.

body.head: To the Pastors, and Elders, and Deacons assembled in Consistory London.
body.p:
HAving understood that some Elders have given it out, that if we would pay the Charges of the other Churches Deputies, we should have a Colloquie; This made me to addresse my self to Mr. Tainturier to demaund of him, If there was any such thing. He told me, that there was such a proposition made. I told him, if there was no hinderance, but the want of money. I would undertake to furnish it, if they would call a Colloquie suddenly before it was Winter. I told him that I had yet so so much affection for the peace of the Church, that I would inlarge my self for the good of it. I told him, that our Church hath had Charity towards other Churches, when they were in division, as Norwich, and Canterbury, and hath not the Consistory Charity for it self? The Charity unto the other Churches hath it taken away that, which we ought to have unto our own? The Proverb is, that Charity begins at home. Sirs, the
answer that you were pleased to send to me, was, when the two Churches, that have no Pastors are provided, then you would write to the Church, that is to call it, desiring them to call a Colloquie. Sirs, Seeing that you have changed your Resolutions, and found out another delay to put off the Calling of the Colloquie so suddainly, as was propounded, in putting it of untill the Two Churches that have no Pastors be furnished with Pastors, which cannot be done so suddainlie: If that had been told me before, I would not have offered you that expedient. Seeing that you do not keep to your proposition, I am discharged of mine. If I did yeild unto your last proposition, the world would judge me to be prodigall. Considering your former sayings, that the Colloquie ought to be seven or eight moneths hence by course; the Two Churches being not now furnished, and caunot besuddenly, for if they were now upon the place, it would be some time before they could be setled, and then it would be the depth of Winter; & then you will judge the season not fit for them to come. Sirs, Me thinks! At present there is as manie Churches, as in former times, and there might be a Colloquie if you would. Sirs, I do not know why Mr. Stouppe speaks so unworthilie of Mr. Danois and Mr. Payen, saying, who are they? This is to despise them: for what reason he doth, it is known unto himself, But I say, that it is not seemly, that such a young man should be so haughtie to despise others. Sirs, I fear if Mr. Stouppe, and some others (if they can hinder it,) we shall have no Colloquie: for one may say the like of the Two Churches, that have no Pastors; for in all likelihood, they will be furnished with young Ministers, that have not yet exercised the Ministery, and so will not have anie great experience in the government of the Churches: And so it might be said we cannot have Colloquies! Sirs, I conceive that I have left you without anie just excuse; For without doubt if your Cause were good, and just, you would desire to come to a suddain end; for I have offered unto you all the wayes to a Colloquie; or to some Ministers of our Colloquie, or to a Classis, or to the Gentlemen of the Dutch, or to English Ministers, or to anie persons, that are not interressed. My cause is good and just,
and I do not fear to make it appear before all the world. (Gentlemen the Deacons,) I do not know, why the Elders have stayed so long time, before they have called you to have your Advise, and counsell! Sirs, seeing now that they have called you to their Assistance, all that I do desire of you is, before that you do imbrace the one, or the other partie, I desire you to read the sentence of the Colloquie against Mr D'asigny. Secondly, I desire you to read the Commission and order given to the Gentlemen, the Deputies to put the sentence in execution. Thirdly, I desire you to read the Testimonie of Mr. John Doneau against Mr. Cisner. Fourthly, I desire you to read Mr. Cisner's own Letter, and consider it verie well. Then you will have some knowledge of those things; Then you may judge, if Mr. Cisner hath done his dutie, according to his deputation, and Commission, accordingly as he had undertaken it to do. Sirs, there is another proposition that I do propose unto both Companies, that is; Mr. D'obey, and Mr. Bar being 〈◊〉 Mr. D'esmare's, (speaking of the differences,) and especially concerning Mr. Cisner's Letter) in the end Mr. D'obey said, that we had a Letter from Norwich, that they would not submit to the Colloquie before the Deputies went to Norwich. Sirs, there was no bodie at Mr. D'esmare's, but Mr. D'obey, and Mr. Bar, and Mr. D'obey said, we had a Letter. So it appeared by that word (we) he comprehended Mr. Bar also; So Sirs you see that Mr. D'obey and others have kept Correspondence with Mr. D'asigny against the Colloquie, and 'tis apparent that some other Brothren have had a hand in that businesse. So by the sayings of Mr. D'obey, I prove the Testimonie of Mr. Doneau to be true, touching the Correspondence with Mr. D'asigny; for Mr. D'obey doe's acknowledge it. Seeing this is so, then it is no marvell, that the things have been carried so, with such unjustice in the Consistory, seeing that there is of the Company that is guiltie of Mr. Cisner's fault, and are Judges, and parties in their own Cause. Sirs, I do not impute this unto all the Elders, but onelie unto those that are guiltie. This word (we) is of a large extent! then it is no marvell, that those that are guiltie with good and fair words have
carryed away some other Brethren by their Subtilties to be of their Judgement, to justifie the guilty. Sirs, I doe desire you to take this business into serious consideration, and very well to examine it, that you be no longer deceived by fair words; for God has begun to discover, and I doubt not but he will go on to discover more & more, and truth will overcome falshood: Falsehood is but a poor refuge: And I am assured, that in the day of Judgement it will not be to them an hiding place. Sirs, I have another thing against Mr. Bar, which he said at Mr. D'esmare's: Mr. D'esmare said, they had justified Mr. Cisner, before that they had heard us: Mr. Bar said, that was false. I do maintain, that this is true: for those Gentlemen that were then in the Consistory cannot denie it, if they please but to remember, when we presented our selves with the Testimonie of Mr. Doneau, and Mr. Cisner's Letter, the Company would not permit them to be read in the Audience of the Company, and seeing no other Remedie, in part we yeilded; upon Condition, that they would hear us what we had to say, before that they did come to a sentence: The which they promised us, that we should be heard of all, that we had to say. I say, though you reiterated this promise to us, yet neverthelesse you proceeded to the sentence, before that you had heard us speak one word, and you justified Mr. Cisner, and that he was not guiltie in anie thing; and you desired Mr. Delmey, having some power on us for to come to us to persuade us to reconcile our selves to Mr. Cisner. Sirs, you know that this is true, and I am persuaded, that those that were then in Consistory cannot say to the contrarie; for I am persuaded, that the most part of you will not denie the truth. Sirs, I do desire to judge, if Mr. Bar hath done the dutie of an Elder in going about to sow falsities against me. Sirs, Considering the false Reports that are dispersed by some of you, Consider if that does not incite me to justifie my self, by putting out a Narration in publick of what hath passed in these differences, that it might be known to the world the wrong, and injustice, that you have done to me. Sirs, I confesse I am enough inclined to do it, but also I should be verie sorrie to bring dishonour upon the whole Church, for the fault of some few
particular persons; and I see that the divisions increase more and more. Therefore, I say, it is more then time that ye should think of some way of peace, and those have been offered unto you, and the guiltie will not imbrace them, but will have their wills, and that rather the Church should break for once, for a good blow. What good blowe that may be, my simple judgement cannot apprehend! but I say, that they that do delight in troubles, and Contentions, if one should wish them their fill of them, in the end they would find, that they have had too much of it, for their good & Contentment. Sirs, It was my desire at the first to be discharged of this businesse, and trouble, and that I am of the same minde; and that hath made me to propound so manie waies to come to a just peace. Sirs, Seeing that it is not resolved to call a Colloquie, before the Two Churches (now vacant of Pastors) be furnished, and that cannot be done suddainlie: Therefore I once more offer unto you to prevent the evil that may befall, if you do stay the ordinarie time of the Colloquie: I saie, I do offer you to referre all the differences, that do concern me to the Gentlemen the Minister and Elders of the Dutch Church, to determine them, untill the Colloquie be assembled, to put a finall end. This is that which I have to represent to you for the present, and rest.

closer.signed:
Your affectionate servant, (I say)
of them that desire truth and
peace. John Jurin Senior.

body.head: Postscript.
body.p:
IT may be Mr. Bar will saie of this Letter, or Paper, as he said to me on Munday last of those formerlie presented to you, that they were fit to be sent unto Bedlam. Seeing it is a Bedlam that hath said it, I do bear with him. Sirs, seeing that there
is no reason in them, I do desire to have your Consent, that I may make all things publick, seeing that they be onelie fit for Bedlam; It will be greatlie for your Advantage, and will make your Cause verie good! And if you please to condescend to it, then I do desire you, that you would be pleased to let me have the Letter, or the Copy of it in which I spake of the fire, which came so near our Church; for by mistake I have torn the Copie of it, and cannot find all the pieces thereof. I have importuned you verie of ten for it, and you have not granted me it: If you please to let me have a Copie of it, or the Letter it self, I do promise to restore it again to you.

div.p: To this Letter, which I am sure the Consistory had in their hands, I received no Answer.

The differences still encreasing more and more, many particular Members of the Church pressed hard upon the Consistory to call a Colloquie to decide, and end all our differences: In so much that at the length they resolved to call one: And in December wrote their Letters to the Churches, Desiring them to send their Deputies to be here in London on the 10th day of Januarie, 1655. And that they would defray their Charges. But I desire the Reader to take notice, that it is not the ordinary practice to pay the charges of the other Churches; And I never heard, that it hath been done heretofore. But when as the Consistorie propounded it to me formerly, they did so, supposing that I would not have undertaken it: And made it a Subterfuge, and Reserve, whereby to have laid the fault upon us, Yet however Mr. Cisner opposed it, saying, they must then do somewhat for us in recompence. Nevertheless being the Consistorie themselves undertook it, we were very well satisfied; For I am fully assured, that the plurality of the Deputies were such godly and religious men, that they would not be tempted to do any unjust action. At which unseasonable time of the year
the Churches at the Consistorie's request sent their Deputies, excepting onely the Church of Norwich, whose Deputies came not at all. And all the rest being met together in London, desired to form, and constitute themselves into a Colloquie. But the Consistorie would not permit them, unlesse they would promise to joyn with the Dutch Colloquie, which was then sitting: Whereto the Deputies replied, that if after they were rightly formed, they found the businesse too heavie for them, and difficult, then they might joyn with the Dutch, if they saw it good.

Now I would have the Reader understand the manner, and Custom of our Colloquies: Which is, That he who was President of the last preceding Colloquie, in case he was one of the Deputies, is by proper, and peculiar Right to be President in the forming, and constituting of the immediate Colloquie then called together to sit, and act, untill such time, as that afterwards they shall elect, and chose another: And in defalt and want of him, the President ship belongs to the Minister of the place, where the Colloquie doth assemble, by reason of the death, or absence of the former President: And so the said Colloquie being called to meet in London, the Pastor deputed for the Church of London was of right to be President in the mean time, till the rest of the Members of the Colloquie had elected another.

Hereupon it fell out by course, that Mr. Stouppe being deputed for the Church of London, was President for the forming, and constituting of the Colloquie: And because the rest of the Deputies would not promise and condescend to conjoyn with the Dutch, (before they were formed,) Mr. Stouppe being President as aforesaid, would not suffer the Members to form at all in Colloquie. Whereupon those other Deputies said to Mr. Stouppe, That it was not proper, or regular for one Church to command the others, and order them what they must do: For that anie one Church had as much power as the Church of London, And therefore they ought not to take to themselves singlie and apart that
power, and priviledge, which belongs to them all in the generall. Mr. Stouppe perceiving that the other Churches would not do, as he would have them, rose up, and said, Let us be gone; And if I be not deceived, dissolved the Assembly without any calling upon God by prayer.

The Noise, and Rumour of the dissolution of our Colloquie being conveyed to us, some fathers of families, together with Mr. Fervacques, and my self, who had all of us served as Elders, met and considered, what we should do upon these unheard of Carriages of the said Consistorie; It being on a Saterday in the afternoon, and some of the Deputies having given out in speeches that they would return homeward on the Munday next following. And thereupon some of us resolved to go to all the Deputies and to desire them not to depart the City for some few daies; Requesting them to do the work, for which they were come up, and not to be discouraged; For we doubted not but that God in his mercie would make them Instruments to settle all the differences in our Church. We addressed our selves to them accordingly and told them, that the morrow being the Lords day, we intended to go to the Consistory, and desire them in the fear of God not to let the Deputies depart, till they had done their work; For which Gods providence had brought them to London to agitate. Accordingly on that Lords day we sent two of our Brethren to the Consistorie, before the first Sermon, desiring them to stay after Sermon, for that some fathers of families would come to propound something to them; But as soon, as the Sermon was ended, Mr. Cisner went out one of the first among the people. Nevertheless we presented our selves to the Companie, desiring to speak a word, or two with them; Who desired us to come again in the afternoon; Because, as they alledged, they had no Minister; But we pressed them then to hear us, and they might report our Requests in the Consistorie in the afternoon very well; For we feared indeed that they would serve us so then in the afternoon, as they had done in the
morning. But however they would not hear us; And therefore we attended them again in the afternoon, and some of us were called in to the Consistorie; Who informed them, that our coming to them then was, upon the report, that we had heard, that our Colloquie was dissolved, whereby all our good hopes were frustrated; Desiring them in the fear of God to weigh and consider the Importance of that businesse; For as much as that they called the Colloquie to end all our differences, and there was noe reason, that they should send the Deputies away without effecting that, for which they were to assemble; And we further requested them to call them together: Whereupon they intreated us to withdraw, and they would give us their answer. Being with-drawn, they sent out two of their Members to us, Desiring us not stay, and they would send an answer to some of us that night. At which very instant two Elders of the Dutch Church in London, having heard how the French Consistorie had dissolved our Colloquie, came to them, desiring them likewise not to permit the Deputies to depart: Who so far prevailed with that Consistorie, as they caused them to meet again on Munday following, to try what might be done; and also they sent word to one of us, that they desired the Deputies should meet again that Munday. Who accordingly did meet; But the Consistorie would not at all decline, or depart from their former Resolutions: And thereupon the Deputies refused to be under their Check, or command; To which if they had summitted, they would have much injured all our Churches, and infringed, and broken our government: And the Consistorie thereupon obstinately dissolved them, and returned them their Letters of Deputation. Of which passage the Dutch Colloquie hearing the same night about eight or nine of the Clock, they thereupon sent two of their Members to all the Deputies of the French Churches, Intreating them not to with-draw themselves, but that they would once more meet together: And for that purpose also desired the French Consistorie of London to depute some Members, as they themselves would do the like, that they with our Colloquie being in conference together, might
try to obtain a right understanding between them. Upon this Proposition a meeting was procured, and something was agreed to be presented to the Dutch Colloquie to consider of. And the next day after the Deputies of our Churches, and the Consistorie presented themselves to the Dutch Colloquie; upon whom they attending in the Dutch Church, there happened a discourse between Mr. Stouppe and some of our Deputies; In which Mr. Stouppe said, that the Consistorie had ordered, that they would not defray the Deputies Charges any longer than that day. Whereupon Mr. Le Queux replyed to him, that then their businesse was at an end; For that they were deputed upon the Consistorie's promise to defray their Charges, and since that it was so they could stay no longer; And it was in that respect but in vain to trouble the Dutch Colloquie. And hereupon Mr. Le Queux went to the Dutch Colloquie, and informed them what Mr. Stouppe had said. Whereupon they sent for Mr, Stouppe, and demanded, If the matter was so; Which he said, was ordered by the Consistorie; And he beleived, (it being their full intention) they would not altet it. And thereby our Colloquie was absolutely dissolved.

By which passages it is very easie to apprehend, that the Consistorie did not dare to come to a Triall, because they could not induce, or obtain the Deputies to act, as they would have them: For one of them said by way of Question, What reason have we to pay your Charges, If you will not do, as we would have you? Thinking that by their paying, and defraying their Charges, the Deputies ought to have done nothing, but what, and as they pleased. But as their hopes were vain, so were they therein disappointed; For some of the Deputies had better principles of honour and integrity, and could not be inticed to act unjustly, nor to overthrow, and destroy our government. But the Consistorie did very ill reward them for their great Love, and affection to the peace of all our Churches, who manifested the same by their coming such journeys at such an unseasonable
time of the year,) by uttering, and vomiting out opprobrious, and disgracefull speeches against them; Accusing them to be partiall to the Dutch Colloquie; And vilifying some of them with very unworthy, and unchristian expressions.

True it is: It was an ungodly, and wicked Reward; but what shall we say! Can we expect an evil tree should bring forth good fruit! My expectation being thus deceived of attaining an end by our Colloquie, not long after meeting with Mr. Ʋanney (one of the Elders,) I told him, that I desired to come to an end of the difference, for that it was not well pleasing to me; Requesting him to propound to the Consistorie, that I was content to refer my business to the Dutch Consistorie to hear and determine it in the fear of God, without having any respect to persons; upon Condition that the Consistorie, and my self should first subscribe to submit to their Determination. Mr. Ʋanney accordingly presented my said proposall to them, who returned me their Answer, that they were willing to refer the Difference to a Coetus. Upon which I demanded of him, whom he meant by the word, Coetus. He answered, the Dutch and French. What? I replied, will you be judges in your own Cause? Is that just? He thereupon said to me, that if I came to complain against them, then they would with-draw. I thereupon asked him, If he thought I would not come against them? And if so, that they would depart, who then they would leave behind them? Whereto he said, The Dutch. Then I again replied, Then what difference is there, for I offered them to leave it to the Dutch Consistorie: But I suspected, that there was something more in the business, that he did conceal from me; For that if I should have referred my self to the Coetus, & then complain against the French Consistorie, and they thereupon depart from the Dutch, They would say, It could not be a Coetus without themselves; And I told him, that I beleeved, that this was their intention; And was my self of opinion, that a Coetus could not be of the Dutch onely; And therefore, they were not
in presence with the Dutch, they would say, It was no Coetus; Wishing him not to think that they should be Parties, and Judges in their own Cause. And thereupon I resolved him, that I would send my Answer in writing to the Consistorie. And accordingly I conferred with Mr. Fervacques, and we agreed upon the Propositions following; Signing, and delivering them to Mr. Ʋanney, and requesting him to present them to the Consistorie; which he did: The translated Copy whereof from the Originall in French I present to the Reader, viz.

div.head: To the Gentlemen Pastors, Elders, and Deacons of the French Church in London.
div.p: IT hath pleased you to send to us Mr. Uanney, and Mr. to propound to us, to know, if we would condescend to referre our differences between you, and us to the Coetus:

Sirs, you are not ignorant, that we have often offered you divers waies, and means to come to a good, true, and just peace, according to the word of God, and our discipline: and we are yet of the same judgement, and desire. Therefore, Sirs, we do give this answer to your proposition, (according to our sense,) that we do not find it expedient, nor fitting to referre the differences to a Coetus; because it is composed of your selves, and the Dutch, and Italians: If they be a Church, it is but newly formed; So that they have no experience in our Church-government, and discipline: And moreover he that is to be their Pastor, (having been a Fryar, or a Religious man, being made so newly a Minister,) these divisions coming before him, in the first beginning of his Ministery, may be a stumbling-block, and offence and scandall to him. Sirs, To shew you, that we are very desirous to come to a good end, which shall be for the glorie of God and the good and peaceof the Church, We do propound, as followeth.

First, We do pray, and desire you to do your duty to the Church, that hath the order given her to call the next Colloquie; desiring them to call a Colloquie in the Spring-time, to decide, & determine all the differences that have befallen from the one and the other: For it is the Colloquie, that hath right so to do; for they be our true, naturall, and onelie judges of all the differences, and unto them we have made our appeal, and to them you, and we are bound to submit: for they are the hedge, that doth • ncompasse our Church, and they are the sinows and veins, that do nourish, and streng then the Churches, and their government, and the Phisicians to cure all the Sicknesses, and disorders: And principally it will be the means to raise up the honour of the Colloquie, that hath been troden under foot, because that they could not be suffered to form into a Colloquie. Sirs, These Reasons do incite us to desire you to condescend to this proposition, and we hope, that you will.

Sirs, if the above said should not be accepted, then we do propound this second, if you do judge it fit tng. It is this, If you do please to make choise of some Fathers of families of our Church, (what number you shall judge fitting,) and we shall choose the like number of Fathers of Families, and being agreed of the number, and of the persons, then we will draw a writing, in which we will give them full, and ample power, as anie Colloquies, or Synod have of right, to hear, and determine, and Censure; And to accomplish it from point to point. Sirs, the reason that makes us to propound this, is to prevent, that our disorder, and faults be no more spread abroad, then they be, to the scandall of the nation, wherein we do live.

Sirs, If the above said Propositions do not please you, we do propose this third, that is. That you, and we choose the Pastors, and Elders of the Dutch Church of London to be our judges, to determine upon all the Considerations, and Provisos, as they are laid down in the propositions above said; And if you please to condescend to it, then to draw out a writing according to the propositions above said, and that the one, and every one subscribe it. Then you and we
ought to present the Agreament unto the Gentlemen of the Dutch, praying them earnestlie, that they would be pleased to accept, and undertake to decide all the differences, as above said: And by it God will be glorified, and the peace of the Church re-established; for which we desire and pray. Sirs, though we have propounded the Two last propositions, we do desire, that you would be pleased to accept the first, which is according to our duties. If one doth reject it, it seemes to us to make a breach in our discipline, and government, and dishonour to our Colloquie. Sirs, If you do not accept our Colloquie to be our judges, this shall not be drawn for an example for the time to come, nor to be prejudiciall to our Colloquies. Waiting for your answer, we rest, Sirs.

closer.signed:
Your affectionate Brethren in the
Lord, that desire truth, & peace.
John Jurin Senior.
Dan. Fervacques.

div.p: The answer that we received to this our propossals from the Consistory by Mr. Ʋanney, was, That they did not reject the Colloquie, but would remit the business to the Coetus. Whereupon I answered, that it was an unreasonable Proposition, that they should thereby be Judges, and parties. He replyed to me, That it was the resolution of the Company. And so the Result of all was just nothing. But the Reader may be informed, that the Consistory have been solicitous with the Dutch, to assume upon themselves to be the naturall judges of all the differences: But as I understand, the Dutch would not accept of it.

It hath been also propounded in the Coetus by one of the French Consistorie of London, to re-establish again a Super-intendent; And another of them being in discourse with some of the Deputies of our Churches, uttered in words, That it would never be well in England, till the Bishops were again established; and these are two of the principall men, that bear sway with the plurality of the Consistorie. Whereby one may easily judge, what ill affection they bear to Reformation, since that
they are inclined to return to the Garlick and Onyons of Egypt, and would introduce Episcopacy again, whereby they might rule, Lord, and Tyrannize over their Brethren, without any Controll.

I hold it necessary, since that the Term of Coetus is so often used in this book; and thereby it might be conceived, and apprehended by some, as if it were a part of our government of our French Churches, that the Reader may be informed, and is desired to observe, that the Dutch have no power over the French, or the French over the Dutch; but are distinct from each other in their government. And if the Reader doubt any thing of the truth thereof, I referre him for full satisfaction therein to the book lately published by the Fathers of Families, whereby I hope he will be fully resolved in his judgement.

The Courteous Reader may be pleased also to take notice of this following Relation, whereby he will the better discover, and discern the temper, and Constitution of Mr. Cisner, and his Adherents, and Abettors. And thus it was: That Mr. John Tulier having formerly served in the office of an Elder of the French Church in London, and being very much desirous, that all the differences therein might be again reconciled, did out of his great Love, and pious affection to the peace, and good of the Church, invite to his house all those persons, that had served as Elders with himself and all the present Elders, hoping to have done some good thereby: And at the beginning of their meeting did read the 13th Chapter of 2. Cor. and afterward prayed, and then incited the Company to peace and reconciliation; And having ended his exhortation, not any one replyed. Whereupon he had us up to dinner, and in the Room were two tables set; Mr, Cisner and those that had served formerly sate at the table with Mr. Tulier, and his wife; and Mr. Stouppe and the present new Elders sate at the other table. When dinner was almost ended, Mr. Tulier began again to exhort
to peace; And when he had ended, Mr. Hedlin took up the discourse, and said, that every one ought to acknowledge his fault to God, and each to other; and after that Mr. Hedlin had concluded, none took it up. Seeing that, I said, that Mr. Hedlin had propounded a true, just, and upright ground for a good, and just peace; and I said, for my part wherein I had failed, and done amiss, I would be ready to acknowledge it to God & man, and doubted not, but God would give me grace so to do. Mr. Cisner being sate in the Inside of the table next to M • . Tulier rose up in a very great fury and said, aloud, Sophistry, Sophistry. I said, he was a Sophister that said it. Then Mr. Stouppe said, I told you what it would be, let us be gone: And they all arose up in such hast, as if some great disaster was like to befall them. And Mr. Stouppe said a word or two of Grace, or thanks, but it was • ery short. Mr. Tulier seeing that disorder, said, Gentlemen, I pray you, as we began, so let us end; desiring Mr. Delmey as he began, so that he would end. But as soon as thanks were given, Mr. Cisner, Mr. Stouppe, and most of the present Elders went away; But the others remained a while after. Consider what an unkind reward this was to Mr. Tulier, and also whither such ungratefull guests were worthy of such an Invitation. I leave the world to judge of this Carriage, whither such is the temper of wise, grave, discreet, and prudent men, fearing God.

After this I understood, that the Church of Canterbury, according to the order of the preceding Colloquie, had called a Colloquie to be held at that place on the 12th of May 1656. And thereupon I wrote to the Consistory of Canterbury in French; The translated Copy of which Letter, followeth, viz.

body.p: THe Pastors, and Elders of the French Church of Canterbury.

Sirs, and honoured Brethren, The Cause of this is to desire you, that you would be pleased to signifie to me, if there is any hope, that there will be a Colloquie with you at the time appointed, so that I may dispose of my affairs, and be with you according to mine Appeal. Sirs, I am affraid that our Consistory endeavour what in them lies, that there be no Colloquie, and that doth encourage me the more, that their Cause is not good. Sirs, Considering all the waies and means, that I have used and endeavoured to come to a just end, yet notwithstanding I cannot draw them to come to the touch, to see if their actions be according to the standard. They are verie busie in Coetus for to make them the natural Judges; But the Gentlemen of the Dutch will not accept it on those terms: yet however they have voted in Coetus, that they are competent Judges. But me thinks! they needed not to have done it, for it would have been more for their honour to have stayed, till that they had been chosen to be such. Sirs, it is too manifest that the Consistory hath a good will to break our government, and to re-establish again a Super-intendent; for one of them hath made that proposition in Coetus; But the Gentlemen of the Dutch took no knowledge of it. So that one may easily judge by what Spirit they are lead. But I doubt not, but in a short time God will again raise up, the honour of our Colloquies in despite of the enemies thereof, and will make them appear to the world such as they are, and render to them according to their deserts. Sirs, I do desire you, that you would excuse me, that I have so much enlarged my self. Waiting your answer, I do remain.

closer.signed:
Your affectionate servant,
John Jurin Senior.

div.p: By some mishap I cannot now find the Letter it self, which was sent to me from Canterbury in Answer; And therefore I shall not further enlarge my self thereupon.

By the aforesaid ill behaviours of the Consistory of London all our hopes were even at an end: But unexpectedly the Church of Canterbury, having the charge given them by the last preceding Colloquie, that they should call another on the 12th of May in the year. 1656, as aforesaid, did accordingly do the same; And thereby our hopes began in some measure to revive, and renew in us. And the better to effect, and bring to passe the meeting of a Colloquie, the fathers of families (before mentioned) made application to the said Consistory of London; requesting them, that they would be pleased to put to their helping hand, that the Colloquie might be assembled at the time appointed: But instead of assording their assistance, they did, (as it seems,) rather endeavour to hinder it; For the Church of Canterbury could receive no Answer at all from them, till such time as a second Letter was sent by one of the Elders there to an Elder in London; And wherefore there was no Colloquie at all, the Church of Canterbury are more able to demonstrate, than my self: And thereupon I shall forbear to enlarge my self in any thing, but rather proceed to other particulars conducing to a greater, and more plain Discovery of the truth. Yet one thing may be worthy of the Readers Enquiry, for what Cause Mr. Du Perrier, (who now officiates as a Minister in the French Church at Southampton, and yet hath no other Ordination, than of a priest in the Church of Rome, wherein he took his Orders, and therefore ought not by our Discipline, and government to be admitted, or received into any of our Churches) did come over from the Isle of Garnsay into England; And when the Consistory of London obstructed, and prevented the forming of our Colloquie before mentioned, they then shewed themselves very kind, and courteous to the said Mr. Du Perrier, lending to him ten pounds in money, to be repaid to them again,
when he shall obtain an Augmentation to be laid to his Pastor-ship from some English living.

This may be said for further satisfaction of the Reader, that some other of our French Churches, being so notoriously affronted, and evilly entreated by the Consistory of London, were wholly discouraged, and had no great desires to meet in Colloquie, conceiving they could do little, or no good. And so no Colloquie assembling, the said Consistory proceded more and more to trample all the rest of their Brethren (as it were) under foot. Which Ambition of theirs constrained some Fathers of Families, who (having made divers offers and Proposalls for peace according to our Discipline, but all were rejected by the Consistory,) could discover no other waies, or means of Redress, humbly to make their Address to his Highness the Lord Protector. And after some time spent, they by his gracious favour obtained a Colloquie, that they should meet and determine all our Differences.

But a little while before such Relief was prayed from his Highness, Mr. John D'oneau came from Canterbury to London: Concerning whom the Consistory of London had given out in speeches, that he was run away, and would not appear before them. Of whose Coming Mr. Fervacques having knowledge, acquainted me therewith: Desiring (in respect of that Aspersion) that we might go to some of the Consistory, and give them notice of Mr. D'oneau's presence in London; for that he was the same day, or the next morning to return to Norwich. Wherefore we being at the Exchange, did inform Mr. Isaac L'illers (one of the Elders,) of Mr. D'onean's being in town, who had testified against Mr. Cisner: And being the Consistory had formerlie said, that he was run away, and durst not shew himself, they might do well to speak with him. He answered, that he could not do it of himself, for that he might in so doing be censured. We therefore desired him to speak with some of his Brethren: And
at the very instant we espied another of the Consistory; requesting Mr. De Lillers to go to him, and consider of it, and return us their Resolution presently, for that Mr. D'oneau having earnest business at Colchester, was to be gone that night or next morning early, that he might be at that place on Saturday night. But at that Exchange-time they gave us no Answer: But after dinner they sent to Mr. Fervacques, that Mr. D'oneau should come to Mr. Bar's house about five of the Clock that afternoone.

I told Mr. Fervacques, that as I did believe, if they were wise, the Members of the Consistory would not meet with Mr. D'oneau at the place appointed; For that there might, or would be some new matter, or evidence discovered. But when the hour was come, Mr. Fervacques together with Mr. Du'quesne, and Mr. D'oneau did go to Mr. Bar's house, leaving notice thereof for me at my house; upon which I did immediately repair thither. Where being come, the party of the Consistory would have persuaded Mr. D'oneau to go into another Room, wherein Mr. Cisner, and some Elders were met together: For that Mr. Bar said, there were other persons besides Mr. D'oneau; And things would be otherwise reported, than they really were. Whereupon Mr. D'oneau replied, that he gave him a good Caution, and therefore he would not speak any thing, but in presence of Witnesses: Upon which Mr. Bar pressed him to come on the Lords-day following to the Consistory: But he said, he could not stay so long, for that he was to be at Colchester on the Saturday night: But if that in case he could stay, he resolved not to speak any thing before them, unless there were more persons present, than at that time were attending to bear witness.

It so fell out at that time, that we could by no means prevail with Mr. Bar, and Mr. Isaac De Lillers, that Mr. Cisner, Mr. D'obey, (and as I think) some others of them then present, that they and we together in person should hear what Mr. D'oneau
would testifie: But instead thereof they unworthily taxed us, that things would be falsely reported. To prevent which, we propounded, that whatsoever should be said by one, or the other party, should be written down and signed, and affirmed by either: But this would nothing at all move them; And therefore I wished them, that they should not give out any more in speeches, that Mr. D'oneau durst not shew his face; But that they would rather acknowledge, that Mr. Cisner durst not shew his. But indeed Mr. Cisner may be accounted wise to disappear, for if he, and Mr. D'oneau had come face to face, no doubt, but that Mr. D'oneau would have revealed some other particulars, than what he had done before; And besides there would have been more Witnesses to his Relation, than formerly. But being we could not induce them to a personall meeting, (as before is mentioned to be desired by us,) we took our leave, and departed: Yet further as I told those Gentlemen of the Consistory, that if it had been my case, as it was Mr. Cisner's, that Mr. D'oneau should (as Mr. Cisner said) have related a false thing of me, I would have sought him, If he had been to have been found above ground: But certainly, when Mr. Cisner fully knew, that Mr. D'oneau was in the same house with him according to his appointment, and Expectation (or else why came he thither?) and yet he would not speak with him; It must needs declare him to be guilty of what Mr. D'oneau had accused him. For if he could have cleared, and vindicated his innocence, We should for our parts have been very glad thereof, and also desirous, that Mr. D'oneau in making his first relation to Mr. Fervacques, whereby to traduce and scandalize Mr. Cisner, should therefore have suffered due Censure, and Reproof; As well we may expect, that Mr. Cisner should yet undergo the same, for his being backward, and averse to give satisfaction for his offence, of which he plainly stands convicted by his silence, and obstinacy.

The Reader shall further discern the rancour, and obstinate
behaviour of the Consistory of London, who, when that his Highnesse had graciously granted us (as before I have related) the Liberty of a Colloquie, did neverthelesse petition against it; Accusing them unworthily to be partiall, and falsely affirming, that the Dutch were our naturall Judges: Which petition they prosecuting at White-Hall with much earnestness, at the length some Fathers of Families (with my self) being by Gods good Providence at that place, and discovering their Attendance, were at length on both parties called in before his Highnesse; where, upon his Highnesse heating the Allegations on both sides, those Gentlemen in the end confessed, that the Colloquies composed of the Members of our own French Churches, were our proper judges; and also professed, that they were never against them; promising before his Highnesse, that a Colloquie should assemble. Concerning the time of whose meeting, and the manner thereof, and how they were not rightly constituted, nor did regularly act, being they were but five persons, and all of them not properly qualified, & also were disclaimed and disowned by six other lawfull Deputies, and the Consistories of severall Churches, I shall herein forbear to relate, but do referre the Reader to the Book of the Fathers of Families before mentioned, being a Refutation of a book before printed by the Consistory. But give me leave to inform you, so farre as I was my self concerned at the meeting of that pretended Colloquie, (for so I must call it,) in as much as his Highnesse, and our Churches were abused, viz: himself in his pious, and gracious Intentions, and our selves in our Discipline, and Government; And so I shall make my progress to declare the truth, and nothing else.

Those five persons under the notion, and pretence of a Colloquie about two daies before their Dissolution sending for me, as soon as I had but notice I appeared before them; Desiring to know for what Cause they had sent for me. They said, to demand of me, If that I had any thing against the
Consistory of London. I answered, yes, and also against Mr. Cisner in particular: But I told them, that I did see but onely five persons of them sitting, who could not make up a Colloquie. They said, that they were six, yet I could see (as again I affirmed) but onely five. Whereupon they replied, that there was an Elder come from Dover, & was here by eight of the Clock that morning, and that he was then admitted. I said to them that it was very strange to me, for that Elder, that was chosen by that Church, and sent up to London, and being newly come, did by Constraint depart again from thence homewards by reason of his Highnesse's Proclamation, for that he had born Arms against the Parliament. This was on the Saturday at noone that I appeared before them, and that Elder left the City but the Thursday night late before, and could not be at Dover at soonest, before the night following; On which night I beleeved both the Consistories there had not met together to make a new choice, (in case they were informed of the necessity of the cause) to give him a Letter of Deputation, which could not in any possibility be here by that Saturday morning by eight of the Clock; Whereupon I desired them, that they would be pleased to receive Mr. Le Queux, and his Elder deputed from Canterbury, and then I would proceed to declare against Mr. Cisner and our Consistory. They answered, that Mr. Le Queux might come, if he would: I desired again, that both he and his Elder might be received, for then they would be the plurality of our Churches, and then I would declare my Complaint: Forasmuch as, that albeit they were six persons rightly qualified; Yet not being the greater part of the Deputies of all our Churches, they could not be properly a well constituted Colloquie. And this passage was on the Saturday afore mentioned after twelve of the Clock; At which time I left the Company, and repaired to the Exchange, where I met with Mr. Le Queux, and acquainted him with what I had said to them, and what was the Companie's Answer to me: He assured me, that he and his Elder would attend them at two of the Clock that afternoone, to try
what they would do; And they did so: But the Company would not receive either of them. By which may well be collected, how light, and triviall a matter they accounted it, to tell an untruth, whereby to deceive their brother.
