Immediately after at the same Exchange-time on the Saturday aforesaid, meeting with one of the Elders sitting (as in a Colloquie,) at that place, I asked him, how it could be possible, that they had received another Elder from Dover so quickly; Who answered me, That the Minister of Dover did choose him, and the Colloquie approved of him. Whereupon I demanded of him, whither this was according to our Discipline and Government: For that the right of the Choice is by the Minister, Elders, and Deacons of the Consistory, and without them together no Deputy could be chosen to be sent to the Colloquie: I said also to him, that I did marvell to see things, carried altogether so contrary to all Rule and Government; whereby I did see, that they had a minde to destroy our good Government. And thereupon I desired of him, that I might know, who it was, that was so newly chosen: To which he gave me answer, that it was Mr. De Haze. On which I said to him, that that person had been a good while in the City, and was then no Elder at that present at Dover, & was also Mr. Cisner's Brother in law, and the very man, that preferred Mr. Cisner to our Church in London; whereby in truth one might easily see, how unrighteously they walked, and that none could expect a blessing from their procedings, because they did behave themselves fraudulently therein.

On which Saturday the Deputies of the Church of Santhoff arrived in London; And on the Munday morning following the Minister of that place (to wit) Mr. Kerhuel, (his Elder being not well at his Inne,) presented himself singly to the Company; And the same time also Mr. Le Queux and his Elder, presented themselves to be received: But the pretended Colloquie told them, they were not a Colloquie at the present, but desired them to come again in the after noone; After those aforesaid were
dismissed, then the Fathers of Families and the four Deacons, and my self presented our selves to them; Intending to have desired of them to receive the above said, and then we would declare. But we desiring to speak with them they told us, that they were not a Colloquie, but desired us to come again to them in the after-noone. So all we the above-said attended them again at that time, and waited a long time upon them; and at length they sent to all of us word, that they were not a Colloquie, because one of them was wanting, and desired us to come to them again the next morning. Accordingly we all appeared as appointed; And then they called in Mr. Le Queux, and his Elder, but would not admit them to their Company. They also called in Mr. Kerhuel, (whose Elder was not well in health,) telling him, that they could not receive him, for three Reasons, viz. First, Because he had received imposition of hands by English Ministers; Secondly, because there was not written on the Top of his Letters of Deputation, (A Messeurs, Les Messeurs the Ministers and Elders in Colloquie.) Thirdly, Because he was come too late with his Elder, for that they had almost done. He desired earnestly to be received, whereby he might joyn with them to strengthen them, and confirm such Acts, as were just, and right. They denyed him, saying they could not. Thereupon the Fathers of Families, the four Deacons, and my self presented our selves to them; Requesting them to receive the said two Churches, there being then sufficient persons enough to constitute a Colloquie. And that on the morrow the Church of Thorney-Abbey would also be with them; And then the Colloquie would be composed of all the Churches; Pressing them, that we might be heard, what we had to say, whereby an end might be made of our unhappy, and ungodly Differences. Upon this they desired us to withdraw, and being a while with-drawn, they did rise, and depart, with out calling us in again; but sent to us the Minister of Dover, who informed us, that they could not proceed, because that we stood for a full Colloquie. Then we suspected, they were dissolved
and therefore we urged him to let us know, whither the Colloquie was dissolved; To which he would not return any Answer. And as farre as we could discover from some others of them, the Colloquie (as they pretended themselves to be) at that very instant (being Tuesday before noone) did absolutely dissolve.

With most fervent desire I beseech the Courteous Reader to consider the order, and manner of procedings of the aforesaid five men, who did take upon themselves the name of a Colloquie, when as they were not the plurality of our Churches; And with all to observe the falseness, and deceipt of their Answer at their breaking up, imparted to us by the Minister of Dover. For asmuch as that they did nevertheless before their Departure confirm the three Acts, made by the Consistory of London wrongfully against Mr. Delmey, and also pass other pretended Acts against the Fathers of Families, (As is more amply related in their aforesaid Book,) keeping them secret, without sending for any of the parties concerned, whereby to admonish, and persuade them by Reasons significant, that they would submit to their Sentences, or otherwise they would make them publick to the People in the Pulpit. But on the contrary, and in a most unchristian manner they did the next Lords day after publish them in the Pulpit; Although they had told us, that they could not proceed, because we stood for a full Colloquie. I pray the Reader to observe this ungodly dealing!

Also I intreat the Benevolent Reader to take notice of the Discipline of our Churches; which is, that every Consistory of each particular Church must have the Major part of the Ministers and Elders, whereby to make them capable to Act, as a Consistory. Much more rather then (I say) ought a Colloquie to be composed of the plurality of Deputies of our Churches at the least; And indeed by our government, they ought all to be present from all the Churches, whereby the Major part of them
might have the affirmative, or Negative votes; As more fully appears by the aforesaid book of the Fathers of Families. But from hence may be drawn into an unquestionable Argument, that the procedings of those five persons were so farre without example, as that the like hath not been heard of in any reformed Churches, throughout the world; And in it self most plainly contradictory to our common practice in the ordinary exercise of our Discipline, and government: For that we never use to publish any Sentence to the disgrace of any offender whatsoever by name, though for never so gross a sin at the first; nay, nor untill after three severall Admonitions to persuade them to repentance and Amendment. And of this I will vouch a late Precedent in our Church, which is this; that a woman (a Member of the same) running away from her husband with another man, the Consistory published onely, that a sister (without nameing her) had committed a foule sinne. But these Gentlemen without any Consideration, immediately (as aforesaid) make a publication by name of their brethren, as offendors. But well we may say, they might do it, for that (right, or wrong,) one of them said to Mr. Le Queux, Whatsoever they did they must save the honour of the Consistory: And Mr. Cisner himself said amongst them, (desiring them to make hast) that if the other Churches did come, his Consistory would be undone. And another Deputie affirmed, that it would never be well in the Churches, till there were Bishops again. But it is to be considered further in what Post-hast these Gentlemen made their progress, when they heard, and plainly did see, that two Churches were here, and the last on their journey, and the next day would attend them; And if they had had that good affection to the peace of the Church, as they should have had in love to justice, and truth, they would have received them all, though they had stayd two, or three daies longer; Whereby to have the judgement, and consent of all the other Churches together with themselves. But I must confess, well weighing the Experience of these five Gentlemen, (for three of them never were in a Colloquie before,
and the other two not in many,) they were nimble, to dispatch such weighty matters in so very short a time: However I shall say, that for what concerned me, or Mr. Fervaeques they did not any thing therein. The reasons wherefore they did not, I conceive may be, either For that two other Churches were here already, aad the other of Thorney-Abbey would be with them on the next Wednesday morning, or that they were conscious to themselves that the business against Mr. Cisner and Consistory, was very foul.

After the departure of these five per sons, there was severall Overtures, and proffers for peace used by the Fathers of Families and my self (As in their book is related more at large) to the Consistory of London, whereby to appease our Differences, I finding no other Remedy, did pen this ensuing Adress to them in French, And Indevoured to deliver it unto the Consistory by my Elder, but they knowing that it came from me, they would not receive it. So that I was constrained to Carried it my self to them & with much a do I obtained leave to read it in their presence, the translation whereof I render you, vix.

body.head: Superscription. To Messaurs the Pastors, Elders, and Deacons of the French Church in London.
body.p:
YOu are not ignorant of the severall propositions which I have offered to you from time to time; hoping, that they would have Induced you to have put a finall end to the difference befallen between
Mr. Cisner, you and my self. Seeing that it hath continued so long a time, and that there is nothing done in it; And the greatest evil is, that there is no hope of the doing of it; seeing that our Churches are so torn and devided on against the other, so that we cannot have a Colloquie, that may cure our evil in the Estate into which they are put, The which is the greatest judgement of God that hath befallen them since their being in this nation, And that ought to be unto us matter of great humiliation before God, And all true Christians that have the glorie of God in singular recommendation and the good and the peace of our Churches; they ought to study how they may bring water to quench this Inflamed fire. And I conceive this Obligation is principally upon you because of the solemn promise that you have made unto God in the face of the Congregation, the which I do pray you well to consider. Sirs, I do acknowledge that it is also my dutie, Therefore to testifie the very great desire that I have that the above said difference be decided in the fear of God; I do conceive that such a way may yet be found out, if it pleased God so to Incline all our hearts unto such a just and holy resolution. So that truth and peace might imbrace each other it proceeding from a heart truely humbled in sincerity, so thereby God will be glorified. Sirs, the proposition that I desire to propose unto you is: That there be very manie English Ministers in this Citie that are pious and fearing God, and that are of the same government with us. I say Presbyterians, and that have not taken part with the one or with the other partie; so that they may be Competent judges, In giving them full and ample power, that the Colloquies have of right for to examine and determine the difference between you and me. And I say that I will submit unto them with heart and affection, not doubting but they will give sentence according to equitie and justice, so by the blessing of God it may be the first step to bring one peace even unto all the other differences In the Church. Sirs, I hope that God will incline you to accept of this proposition; praying you to Consider it maturely in his fear, so to prevent the increase of the evil between you and I for if you will not remit the decision of it unto persons not Interessed and
fearing God; you will Oblidge me to do that which ought not to be done in following your own steps: I say in that which is truth for my justification unto all the world, praying you to prevent it and to Condescend unto that which is just, and right before God and men. And desiring you to do me that favour as to send me your Answer in writing for which I wait and rest.
body.closer:
Your brother that desires nothing
else but truth and peace.
John Jurin Senior. Superscribed.
To Messeurs the Pastors, Elders, and Deacons of the French Church in London.

div.p: On the 14th day of the said moneth of October last past I read the foregoing Address to the Company of our Consistory, and because they refused my proffer therein, I thereupon presented my self with the following Second Application made to them in French with new matters proposed, And wherein you will see their answer to my former, The traslation whereof I commend to the Readers perusall, as it followeth.

opener.salute: Sirs, The Pastors Elders and Deacons.

div.p:
THere is now 8th daies since that I prrsented my self unto you with my Letter of the 7th of this present and at length I obtained permition of you to read it the which was adressed unto you,
and presented unto you by Mr. Tainturier the last Lords day. But would not receive it because you understand that it came from me In the which Letter I did labour to stir you up very much to condecend that a final end might be put unto the difference befallen between Mr. Cisner you and my self, and for that end I made this proposition, That you would be pleased to remit the said difference unto some goodly and pious English Ministers of the same judgement and government with us, But that proposition did not please you saying, that that was against our Discipline and government, And that this example might be of evil Consequence for the fewtor. Sirs, I do conceive that the said proposition is not In any thing contrary unto our Discipline as I told you then. So I say again and if you can shew me anie act of Discipline or Colloquie that hath the least shew of dislike of it I will not Insist anie more upon it, And then I told you seeing that you cannot shew me any such act that shew dislike of it. Therefore I said I will produce unto you a example to shew you that it may be done even of our times In the Cause of Mr. Cisner. Where was chosen by Consent of both parts English Scotch Dutch & French Ministers. Thought they could not do anie thing therein, but left it as they found it, and neverless I have not heard of anie of the partes that were sensured by the preceding Colloquies for their yeilding unto such a expedient. Sirs, The answer that Mr. Stouppe gave me was, may be the Colloquie had forgotten to do it, and also Mr. Stouppe said to me that the Company was content to remit it unto the Coetus. Then I said unto you that it seemed unto me unjust, for you will be judges and parties; and also I told you that the Coetus was joyned with them. In the petition to his hight against the Colloquie and that Mr. Callundrine was with them to promote the delivering the petition so that they made themselves parties with you, so that they cannot be competent judges. I acknowledge that one of you said that when the businesse should be debated In Coetus you would with draw. But Mr. Cisner said the contrary as he did not long since In Coetus, when they were prayed that they would make the tenth appear; of the testimonie they gave unto our Consistory which
they have delivered to his height? Then we Complained that they did us wrong In suffering our Consistory to sit with them, seeing that they were parties; & now judges which is unjusti •… . You know very well that Mr. Cisner was there president, and he said that they ought not to with-draw. And if they did with-draw, they were no Coetus: and not on of the Company did again say it. So that it is to apparent that Mr. Cisner dares not trust his and your cause unto anie persons to decide the difference; unless you are judges and parties, I say that it is unjustice. Sirs, seeing that there is no hope to have a Colloquie according to our Discipline in our daies. Because of the great afronts that you have done unto them; Therefore for the last time, I do propose unto you another expedient and that is this. That I do leave it unto you to chouse such persons as you shall think good. Ʋpon Condition that I have the same libertie; And to give unto them full and ample power, that the Colloquies have of right for to examine the on and the others; and that all books and Letters, and Papers, shall be delivered them that they shall require. So that they may come to a final sentence, according to the demerits of the Cause; and that one and every one do promise to submit unto that they shall ordain. And in case that those Gentlemen that are chosen by the one and the other, could not agree they shall have power to make choise of some other person for to joyn with them; so by that means to make a final end. Sirs, me thinks one should do well not to make choise of anie persons that is Interessed in the devision; for in so doing there will be no end. But rather to take persons: that have had no knowledge of it, and this seem unto me the most sclide way to end it; hoping that you will accept the one or the other of these propositions, for to prevent that which will remain unto posteritie, so waiting for your answer I rest.

closer.signed:
Him that desires nothing else
but truth and peace.
John Jurin Senior.

div.p:
The afore recited Address I read to the Consistory the said 21th of October, last past. And their Answer was, that if I presented my self according to the Discipline they would hear me. And that the future they would not suffer papers to be read unto them. So by this they take away from me all the means that I have to utter my thought because that I have not the French so perfectly as to express my self Receiving this short, and insufficient Answer from them, and no other satisfaction, or reparato this day, and having no other mean left me, whereby to vindicate my self from their unjust aspersions cast upon me, and their wrongfull suspension of me from the Lords Supper, (when as I did onely contend to clear my self from Mr. Cisner's false Accusation, the matter wherewith I did seem to reprove him, being so fully justified at the very first by Mr. Fervacques to have been by him related to me, and at the length testified by Mr. D'oncau to be certainly true, and more particuliarly is manifested by Mr. Cisner one Letter; how treacheriously and Judas like he hath dealt with Mr. De Laune and his Church, and especially with our Colloquie that Imployed him in that Deputation, which doth represent all our Churches. So that that Mr. Cisner hath betrayed all our Churches; I therefore caused this Relation of all Circumstances, and particulars from first to last to be imprinted, and communicated to the publick view of the world, but especially of those Gentlemen to whom I have made my dedication hereof, and all Juditious, and well willing Christians, whose favour shall be so farre extended to me, as to be well pleased to read and compare this book; Not doubting, but that their Consideration thereof will regularly lead, and induce to a just judgement, and positive vindication of me in the premisses; And I hope in the end, that Almighty God will be graciously pleased to administer a fitting Redress, whereby I may be justly vindicated. And that those persons who have acted against me with so much unreasonableness, and Inconsideration, and directly contrary to the Discipline and government of all our Churches, in suspending me, as a foresaid,
may have that Censure and reproof, as the Acts, Articles, and Constitutions of our government have provided and established.

For the Conclusion of this my Narrative, I desire the Reader to observe, that I have been credibly informed, that Mr. Cisner hath very lately preached; That the Law is holy, just and good, calling God and the Angells to bear witness, that he never preached against the Law, or ever called it an Hypocrite or the like; Whereas it will be abundantly proved by very many witnesses (then Auditors); That Mr. Cisner, almost two years since did in two severall Sermons publickly preach against the holy Law of God, and since that time maintained the same unto private persons: The first time that he so preached, some (then present) were much offended, especial • y Mr. Beaumont, who went the next day to his Elder and complained thereof desiring him that he would entreat Mr. Cisner to give him satisfaction therein, but all in vain; For in another Sermon, (he having been questioned for the former) was so farr from giving the least of satisfaction, that he maintained what he had so delivered with much more vigour then before, so that very many more were much offended thereat, and made their severall complaints unto their respective Elders desiring that Mr. Cisner might give them satisfaction either by maintaining that his false and erronious doctrine, or by disclaiming it; but nothing could be procured from him accordingly.

Now let the Reader judge, whether this be the way for any true Gospel Minister to take, as first to preach Atheisticall and blasphemous doctrine against the Majesty of God, and his most holy Law; Then to cover his sin, because he cannot make it good by the word of truth; Lasty, to be so impiously wicked, as to dare to call God and his Angells to justifie him in all his wickednesses. But to close up all, thus much I dare be bold to affirm, and that upon good warrant too, That if he doth not repent, God and his own Conscience will be a terrible Witness against him one day.
